1.CE Marking 

This equipment conforms to the EU machinery Directive 2006/42/EC (description A1 below) and EMC  Directive 2014/30/EU (description A2 below).

However, this equipment does not bear CE marking if a custom order item was installed.

A1.

Cautions regarding the official language of EU countries and the language used in operation manuals,  CE declarations, operation screen characters, and warning labels when this equipment is installed in  an EU country.

• All materials except warning labels are written in English only.

NOTE

Warning labels only have pictograms or else include warning messages in English, Chinese, Korean and Japanese  languages.

A2.

EMC description

• Electromagnetic immunity (Immunity)

Complies with test standards as specified by EN 61000-6-2.

• Electromagnetic emissions (Emission)

Complies with test standards for ISM category: Group 1, Class A, as specified by EN 55011.

Complies with test standards for ISM category: Group 1, Class A, as specified by EN 55011.

Class A equipment is intended for use in industrial environments. If used in other environments, ensuring electromagnetic  compatibility (EMC) might be difficult. Refer to EN 55011 standards for detailed information.

Warning labels are attached to the machine body and peripheral equipment to use YAMAHA machines  safely and correctly. Check that the information on each warning label is clearly legible and comply with  the instructions.

2.1 Warning Label Format and Mark Description
2.1.1Warning Label Format
A warning label indicates the degree of hazard by means of a signal word and the color of the signal word  panel as shown below. A mark and a pictogram are also used to emphasize the message.  Labels attached to the outside of machines are basically in four languages (English, Japanese, Chinese,  and Korean) while labels attached to the inside of the machines are only a pictogram.

Warning label format

Warning message and mark (pictogram) example

Path Image Warning label format : 	Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Operator_Manual/Warning_Labels/Safety_Instructions_2_2.1_2.1.1_Warning_label_format.png

2. Warning Labels

2.1.2.Mark Description

The mark of warning label includes following three types. Each mark has its own meaning and is typically  used with a pictogram to emphasize the message.

Mark and pictogram

Marks and examples used with pictogram

| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Definition | Indicates a hazard, how to  avoid the hazard, and potential  consequences of ignoring the  warning. | Indicates a prohibited action  to avoid the potential hazard. | Indicated an action that must  be taken to avoid the potential  hazard. |
| Shape/Color | Yellow triangle with black  border. Pictogram is black on  yellow. | Red circle with slash.   Pictogram is black and located  behind slash. | Blue circle. Pictogram is white  on blue. |
| Message   example | Risk of electrical shock | Do not modify or disassemble  safety cover switch. | Read the manual to understand  procedure before starting  operation. |

“4. Safety”.

4.Safety

To ensure that the machine you purchased is used safely and correctly, always comply with the instructions and rules in this manual regarding safety. However this manual cannot cover all items regarding safety in detail. So it is extremely important that the operator or person handling the machine make correct decisions regarding safety.

4.1 To Ensure Safety

To maintain the safety of the operator or person working with this machine, it is essential that it (including external parts feeders) be installed correctly in compliance with the safety standards and conditions of that country. Complying with the safety regulations and laws of that country is the responsibility of the customer who purchased this machine. The supervisor of this machine must take responsibility to ensure all measures have been taken for machine safety.

4.1.1 Defining Safety

1. Safety has priority over all other operations.

2. Safety is more important than any other task.

3. Safety is the foundation for work efficiency.

4. Safety begins with maintaining (keeping it neat and orderly) the work environment.

4.1.2 Causes of Injuries and Accidents

Most accidents are not something that occurs but something that are caused. Therefore, it is important to make an effort NOT to cause accidents.

Hazardous actions

• Ignoring causes of accidents

• Working or operating equipment in cramped locations

• Working in locations or positions where safety cannot be ensured

• Unsafe machine operation and using equipment whose safety cannot be ensured

• Working or operating equipment at speeds where safety cannot be ensured

• Working or operating machines with safety equipment removed

• Performing work or tasks on top of a machine currently in operation

• Playing around or goofing off during work • Performing maintenance or inspections without wearing safety gear

4.2 Using Safety Gear

Always wear safety gear when operating or servicing equipment.

Helmet: Use during maintenance work.

Safety glasses or goggles:  Use around light harmful to eyes and when applying lubricant and when handling organic solvents.

Respiratory gear: Use when handling organic solvents.

Safety gloves: Use when handling organic solvents. Use when applying lubricant and when handling organic solvents.

4.3 Restrictions on machine Use

4.3.1|Defining Operator and Service Representative

CAUTION Only the operator and service representative having sufficient knowledge of this machine should handle this machine.

Operator

The operator is someone who has been trained by us in machine operation, has a thorough knowledge of the machine operation manual and demonstrates adequate knowledge of machine operation and safety. Main tasks of the operator include pre-operation checks, operation, and making setups (changeovers). The machine is only used in normal operating mode.

service representative

service representative

The service representatives are those trained by us in machine maintenance as well as safety instruction and demonstrate a thorough knowledge of safe handling of the machine according to the type and location of machine operation. They must also understand hazardous sections of the machine and residual risks. Main tasks of the service representative include machine maintenance, repair, adjustment and management of the system. The service representative may make changes to the machine settings and operation in factory adjustment mode.

4.3.2 Restricting machine Operation with Passwords

machine operating levels usable by the operator and service representative (mentioned above) must be restricted by password. This prevents the operator and service representative from using the machine at a higher level than allowed.

4.3.3 Lock Out Main Switch and Air Supply/Exhaust Switch

When the maintenance work is performed with the power supply and the air supply off, make sure to lock the main switch and the air supply/exhaust switch with a padlock as shown below before the work. This is to prevent a bystander from accidentally turning on the power and the air supply during the maintenance work. Also, make sure to lock the main switch and the air supply/exhaust switch with a padlock when the machine is left unused for a long period of time. Manage the key of the padlock according to the customer's rules.

Lock out the main switch and the air supply/exhaust switch

Path Image Main Switch: Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Operator_Manual/Safety/Safety_Instructions_4_4.3.3_Lock_out_main_switch_and_air_supply_exhaust_switch.png

Path Image Air supply: Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Operator_Manual/Safety/Safety_Instructions_4_4.3.3_Air_supply_exhaust_switch.png

content:
4.4 Cautions During machine Operation

• Always make pre-operation checks before powering on the machine.

• Do not use an air blow tool when cleaning the machine.  (Airborne dust will badly affect machine operation.) • stop all machine operation before cleaning around the machine.

• Do not turn off the air during operation.

• Always make periodic inspections to prevent unexpected machine breakdowns.

• Allow only properly trained, experienced workers to perform repair and adjustment.

4.5 Cautions During Power Outage

If a power outage (blackout) occurs during automatic machine operation, always power off the machine to prevent faulty operation and equipment damage after power has been restored. Remove items such as boards that remain inside the machine.

4.6 Cautions Regarding Ferromagnetic Fields

Some machines contain parts generating strong magnetic fields which may cause death, bodily injury, or device malfunction. Always comply with the following instructions.

• Persons wearing electronic medical devices such as cardiac pacemakers and/or hearing aids must not put any of their body parts into the machine.

• Persons wearing ID cards, purses, and/or wristwatches must keep away from the linear motor. • Do not attempt to disassemble the linear motor (including surrounding covers).

• Do not bring tools close to the linear motor.

• Do not bring tools close to the magnetic scale. • Do not put magnetic materials or objects close to the linear motor.

• Do not touch a portion close to the linear motor during operation or immediately after the operation has been finished since such part is hot.

CAUTION

CAUTION

When disposing of a part generating strong magnetic fields such as a linear motor, dispose of it in compliance with the laws and regulations of the country where the machine is used. Contact your distributor for disposal of the parts.

4.7 Handling Internal Tape Cutter

The internal tape cutter could cause severe injury if misused. Adhere strictly the following precautions.

• Never supply electrical power and air to the machine while the covers of tape cutter are removed.

• Never put your hands or fingers into the tape emitting duct of the tape cutter.

• Never touch the tape cutter blade.

• tape cutter maintenance tasks must be performed by your service representative.

NOTE

YAMAHA recommends to inspect a tape cutter (and to lubricate with disassembly if needed) once a year, although this may vary depending on the machine condition or machine operating environment. YAMAHA also recommends to replace tape cutter blade once every three years. Contact your distributor for more details.

4.8 Keeping Hands Away from Moving Parts

During use of this machine, the customer’s equipment and operating conditions might allow the operator’s hands to come into contact with moving parts. Use the following safety measure options to avoid possible danger where openings or gaps are found on the machine.

Dummy feeder

Use dummy feeders as safety measures to fill a gap between tape feeders. Install dummy feeders on the feeder plate the same way as normal feeders in order to prevent hands from entering.

Prevention of hand and object entry

Dummy feeder

Path Image Dummy feeder: Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Operator_Manual/Safety/Safety_Instructions_4_4.8_Prevention_hand_and_object_entry_Dummy_feeder.png

CAUTION

CAUTION

To install or remove a dummy feeder, be sure to first press emergency stop button and then open cover. The machine has structure that does not allow installing or removing dummy feeder when machine is in operation. However, inserting dummy feeder inside cover during operation may cause serious accidents, so be careful not to attempt it.

One-stop cover (for machines with feeder exchange carriages)

When a feeder exchange carriage is not in use on a carriage-type machine, install a one-stop cover in the position where the feeder exchange carriage is to be installed to prevent hand entry.

Prevention of hand entry

One-stop cover

Path Image One-stop cover : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Operator_Manual/Safety/Safety_Instructions_4_4.8_Prevention_hand_entry_One-stop_cover.png

CAUTION

To remove the one-stop cover with the lower opening cover, be sure to remove it while holding its opening with hand and supporting it.

NOTE

NOTE

One-stop covers cannot be installed or removed during operation. The machine must be in a stopped state because the feeder exchange carriage setting part needs to be moved up and down when installing or removing the feeder exchange carriage.

Precautions for using one-stop cover (for machines with feeder exchange carriages)

Using different one-stop covers depending on the safety cover specification will increase safety.

Prevention of hand entry

Precautions for using one-stop cover :

Path Image Check the safety cover specification : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Operator_Manual/Safety/Safety_Instructions_4_4.8_Precautions_for_using_one-stop_cover.png

Path Image Check the safety cover specification2 : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Operator_Manual/Safety/Safety_Instructions_4_4.8_Precautions_for_using_one-stop_cover2.png

Path Image Check the safety cover specification3 : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Operator_Manual/Safety/Safety_Instructions_4_4.8_Precautions_for_using_one-stop_cover3.png

Muzzle plate

Use these plates as a safety measure for the board conveyor entrance and exit openings.  Each plate is movable, so adjust the mounting position to match the boards to be produced.

Muzzle plate

Path Image Muzzle plate : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Operator_Manual/Safety/Safety_Instructions_4_4.8_Muzzle_plate.png

| Supported machine | Upper clearance | Lower clearance | Remarks |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| YRM20 | Dual-stage type | 0 to 40 mm | 0 to 40 mm | From board conveyor surface |
| YRM20 | Single-lane type | 0 to 40 mm | 0 to 40 mm | From board conveyor surface |
| YRM20DL | 0 to 40 mm | 0 to 50 mm | From board conveyor surface |

NOTE

The values above show the maximum adjustable range of the muzzle plate. See the product specification of each machine for the component mountable height and the restrictions of the substrate.

CAUTION

When installing a unit such as a loader or an unloader on the upstream or the downstream side of the machine, set the muzzle plates to the opening of the board conveyor entrance or the board conveyor exit to make the opening small.

4.9 Handling Solvents (Including Solder, Adhesive, and Flux)

Cleaning organic solvents, such as isopropyl alcohol (IPA) and ethanol are used for the maintenance of this machine (including optional units). Additionally, the solder paste printers, dispensers, and some hybrid placers and flip chip bonders use solder, flux, or bond, etc. during normal production. As many of these materials include organic solvents, great care should be taken when handling them.

Cautions on handling solvents

1. Harmful to human body Organic solvents constantly vaporize and contaminate the surrounding atmosphere. Inhaling or coming in contact with organic solvent vapor may cause serious damage to human health.

2. Flammability Organic solvents are highly flammable substances and can easily catch fire if handled improperly.

3. Adverse effects on machines Some kind of solvent may deteriorate parts used in the machine, electric cable sheathes, and other resin parts.

To prevent accidents caused by solvents

To prevent accidents caused by solvents

1. Be careful not to inhale toxic vapors of solvents for extended periods.

2. Do not use solvents near fire or flame. Keep solvents away from flame or fire.

3. Use only the specified solvent in the correct manner. Do not reuse any solvent repeatedly, and do not

mix with other solvents or chemicals.

4. Check the contents of the safety data sheet (SDS), thoroughly notify work personnel of toxicities of

included chemical materials and measures to be taken in case of an accident, and take necessary

countermeasures.

5. Use appropriate safety gear (safety goggles, protective gloves, and respiratory protective devices)

corresponding to the solvent or material types.

6. See the safety data sheet for how to dispose the solvents and the cloths used for wiping off the

solvents.

CAUTION

If no safety data sheets are supplied with solvents or materials you have purchased, be sure to acquire the safety data sheets from the suppliers.

4.10 Handling Laser

This machine (including optional units) has portions using the laser, such as a sensor and barcode reader.

This device is a Class 1 laser product. (IEC60825-1: 2014, FDA (CDRH) Part 1040.10)

Path Image Handling Laser :

Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Operator_Manual/Safety/Safety_Instructions_4_4.10_Hand_Laser.png

CAUTION

Use of controls or adjustments or performance of procedures other than those specified herein may result in hazardous radiation exposure.

Knowledge and information about laser

1. Harmful to human body

Never look at the laser directly even when it is weak. In particular, if the laser is irradiated to an eye

for a long time, this may cause serious injury.

2. Reflection of laser

The laser is reflected by a glass or metal surface. Pay special attention to the reflected laser light

during maintenance work.

To prevent accidents caused by laser

1. Do not align your eye with the laser height so that you do not look at the laser directly.

1. Do not align your eye with the laser height so that you do not look at the laser directly.

2. Shield the laser during work, when necessary.

4.11 Handling Grease and Oil

Grease or oil is applied to the operating axes of this machine. When performing the lubrication work, strictly

observe the cautions shown below.

Cautions on handling grease and oil

1. If grease or oil enters your eye or sticks to your skin, this may cause inflammation. Be sure to wear

safety goggles and protective gloves during work. Additionally, if you swallow grease or oil by

mistake, this may cause vomiting or diarrhea.

2. If grease other than specified is used, this may cause damage to the machine.

3. If grease with different characteristics is mixed with proper grease, this may cause the machine

performance to lower.

4. Be sure to cap tightly after use to prevent entry of dust or water content. When storing the grease or

oil, avoid the direct sunlight, keep it away from a fire, and store it in a dark place.

NOTE

When the safety data sheet (SDS) about the grease or oil that is used for the maintenance wok is needed, contact your distributor.

4.12|Handling Batteries

Batteries are used for some motors of this machine and the optional BACKUP UNIT (Uninterruptible Power

Supply unit).

Cautions on handling batteries

1. Do not disassemble the battery or touch its inside. Otherwise, electrical shock may result.

2. Do not over-heat or apply a strong impact to the battery. Otherwise, fluid leakage, explosion, or heat

generation, etc. may result. Never use the battery, to which a strong impact has been applied, such

as dropping to the floor since its battery fluid may leak.

3. Only engineers who have the experience and knowledge about electrical work are allowed to replace

the battery.

4. The battery may discharge naturally. When purchasing a spare battery, do not store it for a long

period and prepare it one to two months before the scheduled replacement work. Additionally, when

storing the battery, avoid a place where the temperature increases and be sure to store it at room

temperature.

NOTE

temperature.

NOTE

When the safety data sheet (SDS) about the battery is needed, contact your distributor.

CAUTION

See the user's manual prepared by the battery manufacturer that is supplied with the BACKUP UNIT for details about how to handle BACKUP UNIT.

CAUTION

Dispose of a battery in compliance with the laws and regulations of the country where the machine is used.

Contact your distributor for any questions about disposal of the battery.

4.13 Handling|Heavy Objects

This machine (including optional units) may require the operator to handle heavy objects during work. (For

example, magazine or cassette replacement) If you hold up a heavy object in an unnatural posture, this may

cause damage to your back. Additionally, if you fall a heavy object to your feet, this may cause serious

personal injury. Or, falling a heavy object may cause damage to the magazines or internal tray components.

Cautions on handling heavy objects

1. Be careful not to take an unnatural posture during work. In particular, be aware that you may take an

unnatural posture easily when holding up a heavy object from a low place. It is recommended to hold

up a heavy object by bending and stretching your knee instead of bending your waist or prepare a

cart with an appropriate height when necessary.

2. When handles are provided, such as magazine or cassette, hold the handle securely and perform the

work.

work.

3. To prevent personal injury caused by heavy object dropping, be sure to wear safety shoes.

CAUTION

When heavy object handling standards are defined at the customer's factory, besure to follow the standards during work.

helpful information when operating a machine are explained as “Note” and “Tip”.

1 Using This Manual

This manual is intended for machine operators, and mainly describes how to handle and operate YAMAHA

surface mounters and related equipment.

To use the machines safely and correctly, be sure to read this manual thoroughly before use

CAUTION

Before using the machines, always read the “Safety Instructions” in this manual and comply with instructions and rules regarding safety.

NOTE

The control wiring diagram, maintenance support items, error message list and the like can be downloaded from the YAMAHA Surface Mounter Support & service website. See “2. User Support” in Appendix for details.

CAUTION

The parts (parts numbers) in this manual are at the time of issuing this manual. The parts numbers may be changed without prior notice. Make sure to contact your distributor for the latest parts numbers before ordering.

Signal light (with buzzer)

Indicates current operating conditions of the mounter with a green, yellow and red light, or green, white

and blue light explained below.

The buzzer at the top of the signal light sounds if an error or abnormal condition occurs.

| machine status | Example | Green | Red/White | Yellow/Blue |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| During warm-up or   automatic operation | – | ON | – | – |
| In an emergency stop | – | – | ON | – |
| When system error occurs (with buzzer ON) | • Overcurrent  • Secondary limit over | – | ON | – |
| When operating or board  data error occurs  (with buzzer ON) | • Pick-up error, recognition error • Data check error, etc. | – | – | ON |
| Components unusable  state | • Any components have run out or the  Tray Component Supply Unit's door  is open.  • Any feeder exchange carriage is off. | – | – | Flashing |

NOTE

The color coordination of signal light can be chosen when ordering machine from “green, yellow, red” or “green, white, blue”.

The sound volume of buzzer is set as “Low” when shipping.

Component supply indicator

Lights up if there is a shortage of components.

This indicator is an optional item depending on the machine type.

I/O connectors (for I/O signals between machines)

In most case, the mounter dose not stand alone in its operation, but runs in “line” with pre-process/

post-process machines. The mounter ejects the finished board when it receives a signal from the

machine in the next process, and then sends a signal to the machine in the preceding process to

request another board.

The interface connector labeled “NEXT INTERFACE” connects to the machine in the next process, and

the interface connector labeled “PREVIOUS INTERFACE” connects to the machine in the preceding

the interface connector labeled “PREVIOUS INTERFACE” connects to the machine in the preceding

process. In the case of standard machines of right-to-left flow, the PREVIOUS INTERFACE connector is

located behind the rear right cover of the machine, and the NEXT INTERFACE connector behind the rear

left cover.

feeder exchange carriage

Is a carriage dedicated to set feeders for production.

feeders to be used in production are loaded here so they can be batch-loaded onto the mounter.

For details, see “4.2.1 feeder exchange carriage” in this chapter.

Empty tape dust box

The used cut-up pieces of carrier tape are collected in the empty tape dust box.

If the feeder exchange carriage is not equipped, the 32-reel fixed feeder plate is installed on machine

For the machine equipped with the fixed feeder plate, the reel holder is installed in front of the fixed

feeder plate to store tape reels. There are three types of the reel holder, 70-reel holder, 32-reel holder,

and 70-reel holder for full load of Auto loading feeders.

This switch should be ON by turning to  left when setting the carriage (clamp) in position, and OFF by turning to right when  detaching it.  The LED of switch lights during the feeder exchange carriage is clamped, and flashes  during clamping or unclamping. |

NOTE

The [ACTIVE] button is provided on both front and rear (option) panels, but cannot be turned on simultaneously. This means that the [READY], [START], [ERROR CLEAR] and [RESET] buttons are enabled only when the [ACTIVE] key on the same panel is turned on.

Moreover, the [STOP] button and emergency stop button can be used when the [ACTIVE] button is either on or off.

The keyboard (option) is enabled only when the [ACTIVE] key on the front panel is on.

NOTE

The clamping of feeder exchange carriage is performed only when the machine safety cover is closed.

Moreover, the unclamping the feeder exchange carriage is performed only when the machine is under emergency stop.

CAUTION

Remove the feeder exchange carriage after the flashing of the clamp switch has stopped. If the feeder exchange carriage is removed forcibly while the switch is flashing, this may cause malfunction.

3 Head Unit

There are four kinds of head units that can be installed on this machine as follows:

• Ultra-high-speed rotary head unit (hereafter, RM head unit)

• High-speed general-purpose inline head unit (hereafter, HM head unit)

• Inline head unit for special shape components (hereafter, FM head unit)

• Multi-functional inline head unit for large components (hereafter, LM head unit)

As for the machine specifications, you can choose “2-beam type” with two head units, or “1-beam type”

with one head unit. With 2-beam type, you can combine the head units of the same type or different types.

TIP

See the specification sheets for the applicable combinations of head units.

3.1 Component Pick-and-Mount Head

3.1.1 RM Head Unit

The RM head unit has a rotary mechanism and it has 18 pick-and-mount heads per one unit.

There are two fiducial cameras on the left and right sides of the RM head unit and four side-view cameras

at the bottom.

RM head unit

Path Image RM head unit : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Operator_Manual/Head_Unit/Chapter_1_Unit_Names_and_Functionsfront_3_3.1_3.1.1_RM_head_unit.png

The Z-axis unit and V-axis unit are located on both left-and-right sides of the RM head unit.

The Z-axis unit is used to push the nozzle shaft down with a rod to lower the nozzle shaft when picking/

mounting components.

The V-axis unit is used to move the spool (that is, mechanical valve) up and down to perform the necessary

vacuum/air switching during components picking/mounting.

NOTE

When moving the spool down, air will be supplied to the nozzle shaft.

When moving the spool up, the nozzle shaft will be connected to the vacuum line.

RM head unit

Z-axis and V-axis

RM head unit

Z-axis and V-axis

Path Image Z-axis : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Operator_Manual/Head_Unit/Chapter_1_Unit_Names_and_Functionsfront_3_3.1_3.1.1_RM_head_unit_Z-axis_and_V-axis.png

NOTE

The RM head unit does not use the ejector system but does use negative pressure (vacuum) generated by a built in vacuum pump to pick-up components.

Additionally, the entire RM head unit except for the fiducial camera can be moved up down with the HZaxis.

This enables to pick/mount the components with maximum height of 6.5 mm.

3.1.2 HM Head Unit

The HM head unit has ten component pick-and-mount heads.

The maximum height of components that can be picked up by each head is 15 mm.

Two fiducial cameras are located on both sides of the head unit, and the scan camera unit with the sideview

camera on the bottom.

The HM head unit generates negative pressure by ejector system.

3.1.3 FM Head Unit

The FM head unit has five component pick-and-mount heads.

The maximum height of components that can be picked up by each head is 30 mm.

3.2 Nozzle Types

To ensure stable component pick-up, the correct nozzles that match the components must be used.

The following sections describe typical nozzles which can be attached to each head unit.

CAUTION

The nozzles listed below are dedicated to machines of YRM series.

They cannot be used with machines of YSM or YS series.

NOTE

For detailed information on types and sizes of components that can be picked up by nozzles, refer to the specification sheets that come with the machine.

NOTE

The nozzles named “80XX” (e.g. 8004H, 8006H) are called “wide range nozzle”, named “81XX” (e.g. 8101A, 8102A) “narrow-pitch nozzle”. While the wide range nozzles can pick up a large number of component sizes, it requires wider spacing (0.35 mm or more) between adjacent components when mounting components. Each narrow-pitch nozzles has a specified spacing between adjacent components, so refer to the specification sheets that come with the machine.

NOTE

The data matrix with nozzle ID is pasted to each nozzle.

NOTE

The data matrix with nozzle ID is pasted to each nozzle.

The machine reads automatically its ID and manages the nozzles such as storing position in the nozzle station.

3.2.4 LM Head Nozzles

3.2.4.1 Adapter Nozzle and Standard Nozzles

For LM heads, standard nozzles cannot be attached directly to the nozzle arm assembly.

You can use them for LM heads by attaching a standard nozzle to the adaptor nozzle.

metadata.sub_sub_sub_section: 3.2.4.1|Adapter Nozzle and Standard Nozzles

content:
3.3 Nozzle Station (Option)

3.3.1 Overview of Nozzle Station

The nozzle station stores multiple types of nozzles described in the previous section “3.2 nozzle Types” to

perform automatic nozzle change. The nozzle station is comprised of its base unit and nozzle holder

storing nozzles and whole nozzle holder can be attached/detached.

The nozzle station is equipped cylinders to perform ascending/descending the optional nozzle holder unit,

or opening/closing the nozzle holder shutter. The automatic nozzle change is performed by ascending the

nozzle holder unit and opening the nozzle holder shutter.

nozzle station

Path Image nozzle station : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Operator_Manual/Head_Unit/Chapter_1_Unit_Names_and_Functionsfront_3_3.3_3.3.1_Nozzle_station.png

Path Image Ascending the nozzle holder : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Operator_Manual/Head_Unit/Chapter_1_Unit_Names_and_Functionsfront_3_3.3_3.3.1_Ascending_nozzle_holder.png

Path Image Opening/Closing the nozzle holder shutter : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Operator_Manual/Head_Unit/Chapter_1_Unit_Names_and_Functionsfront_3_3.3_3.3.1_Opening_Closing_nozzle_holder_shutter.png

3.3.2 Nozzle Holder 1 and 2

The nozzle station can be installed one per front and rear side of machine. Moreover, two nozzle holders

are equipped per one nozzle station.

The nozzle holder of back side from operator is called nozzle holder 1 and near side, nozzle holder 2,

regardless of it is front/rear nozzle station.

nozzle holder 1 / nozzle holder 2

Path Image nozzle Holder 1 / nozzle Holder 2 : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Operator_Manual/Head_Unit/Chapter_1_Unit_Names_and_Functionsfront_3_3.3_3.3.2_Nozzle_holder1_Nozzle_holder2.png

NOTE

The numbering of the nozzle storage positions described at “3.3.4 Type A nozzle Holder”, “3.3.5 Type B nozzle Holder”, “3.3.6 Type C nozzle Holder”, and “3.3.7 Type E nozzle Holder” will change depending on the position where the nozzle holder is attached.

3.3.3 Nozzle Holder Type

There are four types of nozzle holders: Type A, Type B, Type C, and Type E.

It is selected depending on the head unit type or components to be mounted.

The details of each holder are described at the following section.

Recommended holder type

| Head unit | Recommended holder type |
| --- | --- |
| Head unit | Holder 1 | Holder 2 |
| RM head unit | Type A | Type A |
| HM head unit | Type A | Type B |
| FM head unit | Type B | Type C |
| LM head unit | Type E | Type E |

3.3.4 Type A Nozzle Holder

The following describes the numbering of the nozzle storage positions for the Type A nozzle holder.

The Type A nozzle holder can store up to 38 component pick-up nozzles of small diameter.

Type A nozzle holder

3.3.6 Type C Nozzle Holder

The following describes the numbering of the nozzle storage positions for the Type C nozzle holder.

The Type C nozzle holder can store not only the small diameter nozzles and the bigger 8012H nozzles, but

also the custom nozzles of large diameter. It can store up to 18 component pick-up nozzles including

3.3.9 Detaching/Attaching Nozzle Holder

Detaching nozzle Holder

1. Push down the nozzle holder detaching lever.

2. Lift up the whole nozzle holder and detach it.

NOTE

The nozzle holder shutter is equipped with magnet and it is closed after detaching the nozzle holder.

The nozzle can be detached while shifting the shutter by hand.

Moreover, do not make upside down the nozzle holder with opening the shutter as the nozzles may drop off.

Detaching nozzle holder

Path Image Detaching nozzle holder : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Operator_Manual/Head_Unit/Chapter_1_Unit_Names_and_Functionsfront_3_3.3_3.3.9_Detaching_nozzle_holder.png

Attaching nozzle Holder

1. Insert the nozzle holder so that it hooks onto the mounting block on the nozzle station base unit.

2. Push down the lever side of the nozzle holder while making the mounting block side as a supporting

point.

3. Press the nozzle holder downward. It will click when being locked.

point.

3. Press the nozzle holder downward. It will click when being locked.

Attaching nozzle holder
Path Image Attaching nozzle : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Operator_Manual/Head_Unit/Chapter_1_Unit_Names_and_Functionsfront_3_3.3_3.3.9_Attaching _nozzle_holder.png

NOTE

The nozzle holder has a positioning mark (ANC MACS) and the position of the nozzle holder is calibrated by scanning it with the fiducial camera.

Moreover, a nozzle holder detection sensor is equipped at the nozzle holder attaching position. If the nozzle holder is not attached, automatic operation cannot be started due to interlock.

NOTE

MACS is an abbreviation of “Multiple Accuracy Compensation system” and used to mean the position correction system for YAMAHA mounter or the positioning mark.

NOTE

Be careful not to scratch or dirt the QR code label and ANC MACS, or it may occur a recognition error

content:
Automatic nozzle registration function by the [nozzle registration] button

This function reads a nozzle ID engraved on a nozzle and automatically registers the nozzle storage

position on the nozzle station.

• After checking that nozzles are stored in the nozzle station, the nozzle ID recognition is performed

for the stored nozzles.

• If nozzles are attached to a head, the nozzle ID recognition is first performed for the nozzles stored

in the nozzle station.

Then, the nozzles attached to the head will be stored in the nozzle station and the nozzle ID

recognition will be performed for them.

The actual operation flow is as follows:

operation flow of automatic nozzle registration

Path Image operation flow of automatic nozzle registration : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Operator_Manual/Head_Unit/Chapter_1_Unit_Names_and_Functionsfront_3_3.3_3.3.10_3.3.10.1_Operation_flow_of_automatic_nozzle_registration.png

The timing for starting “Automatic nozzle registration” is as follows:

metadata.sub_sub_sub_section: 3.3.10.1|When “Nozzle Free Layout Setting” Is Set to “Use”

content:
The timing for starting “Automatic nozzle registration” is as follows:

• After performing the Return-to-Origin

• Before nozzle change with no automatic nozzle registration

• After reading the board data with no automatic nozzle registration

• Before starting operation with no automatic nozzle registration

• When clicking on the [nozzle registration] button

In addition, the following operations will cancel the automatic nozzle registration. At this time, the

[nozzle registration] button color changes from blue to gray.

• When canceling automatic nozzle registration in the middle of the process

• When detaching the nozzle holder

• When opening or closing the shutter of the nozzle station

CAUTION

IF THE NOZZLE ID IS SCRATCHED OR DIRTY, AN ERROR MAY OCCUR. MAKE SURE TO HANDLE NOZZLES CAREFULLY.

station.

nozzle verify

This function checks the presence or absence of nozzles for each storage hole in the nozzle station.

• If there is no nozzle in a storage hole on the nozzle station, the machine will recognize that the nozzle

for its storage hole has been attached to the head.

• In machine setting (location: [machine Data] > [Station] > [nozzle station]), set which nozzle is stored

in each storage hole and which head uses the nozzle in each storage hole.

The times for performing “nozzle verify” is as follows:

• Before nozzle change if no nozzle verify has been performed.

• Before starting operation if no nozzle verify has been performed.

• When the [nozzle verify] button is pressed.

In addition, the following operations will cancel the nozzle verify. At this time, the [nozzle verify] button

color will change from blue to gray.

• When the nozzle verify is canceled in the middle of the process.

• When the nozzle holder is detached.

• When the nozzle holder is detached.

• When the shutter of the nozzle station is opened or closed.

3.4 Air-Blow Station

3.4.1 Shaft-Blow Function

The air-blow station provides a high-pressure air blowing cleaning function to blow foreign matter from the

nozzles, inside the shafts and nozzle tip (This motion is called nozzle shaft blow). The air-blow stations

are installed at front and rear side of machine.

Five holes shown in the figure below are used to blow the heads separated in groups.

See the next section “3.4.2 How to Execute nozzle shaft blow manually” for practical method.

Here, components are normally disposed into the dump box. But regarding to the disposal of

microminiature components as such 1005 size or smaller, if some components or dust are recognized at

checking after disposal operation (by negative pressure check or side-view recognition), the air-blow

station continues shaft blow dump to dispose microminiature components.

See the section “3.4.4 Shaft Blow Dump of Microminiature Components” for practical method.

Air-blow station and dump box

For DS, SL type

Air-blow station and dump box

For DS, SL type

Path Image For DS, SL type: Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Operator_Manual/Head_Unit/Chapter_1_Unit_Names_and_Functionsfront_3_3.4_3.4.1_Air_blow_station_and_dump_box_For_DS_SL_type.png

For DL type

Path Image DL type : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Operator_Manual/Head_Unit/Chapter_1_Unit_Names_and_Functionsfront_3_3.4_3.4.1_Air_blow_station_and_dump_box_For_DL_type.png

NOTE

There is no difference in the shaft-blow function in both types of the air-blow stations shown above.

Side blow

Cleans the nozzle tip by air-blow from side when the nozzle shaft-blow is performed.

Air-blow station filter

The filter for the side-blow line in the air-blow station.

Dump box

A box to dispose the discarded components.

Dump box confirmation sensor

Checks the dump box presence and floating status.

NOTE

The automatic operation cannot be started without the dump box in its position.

Exhaust box

NOTE

The automatic operation cannot be started without the dump box in its position.

Exhaust box

Stores dust and vert small chips disposed by the nozzle shaft-blow.

3.4.2 How to Execute Nozzle Shaft Blow Manually

This section explains how to manually perform a nozzle shaft blow at any desired timing.

Step 1 Open the [Unit] > [Head] tab screen.

Step 2 Press the [Cleaning Blow] button.

nozzle shaft blow

Example: HM head unit

Path Image Example HM head uni : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Operator_Manual/Head_Unit/Chapter_1_Unit_Names_and_Functionsfront_3_3.4_3.4.2_Nozzle_shaft_blow_HM_head_unit.png

Step 3 Specify the nozzles you want to clean by nozzle shaft blow.

The “nozzle Setting” screen will appear. Select the table where the nozzle shaft cleaning blow is

performed, put a check mark on the nozzles, and then press the [OK] button.

nozzle setting screen

metadata.sub_sub_section: 3.4.2|How to Execute Nozzle Shaft Blow Manually

content:
CAUTION

When the nozzle is not subject to the nozzle shaft blow, the nozzle may collide with the air-blow station, causing breakage. Before starting the nozzle shaft blow, be sure to check that the set nozzles meet the installed nozzles.

Step 4 A confirmation screen appears asking you to make a final check.

Check the contents of the screen and press the corresponding button.

[YES] button: Executes nozzle shaft blow of the selected nozzles.

[NO] button: Returns to the “nozzle setting” screen.

[CANCEL] button: Closes the dialog box and returns to the [Unit] > [head] tab screen without

executing nozzle shaft blow.

Safety checks

metadata.sub_sub_section: 3.4.2|How to Execute Nozzle Shaft Blow Manually

content:
Safety checks

The nozzle shaft blow function also contains the following safety checks.

• nozzle shaft blow interruption alarm

The head immediately rises if operation stops during nozzle shaft blow due to emergency stop or an

interlock triggering. If the head rises but the air blow still continues, then the nozzle might come

loose from the head. To prevent this, a confirmation dialog box appears if the machine operation

stopped during nozzle shaft blow.

• nozzle sensors to check whether a nozzle is left on the air-blow station

The nozzle shaft blow function forces high-pressure air through the nozzles during cleaning, so the

nozzles might come loose from the head if machine operation stops during nozzle blow. If a nozzle

comes loose from the head and remains on the air-blow station while the automatic operation still

continues, then the nozzle left on the air-blow station might interfere with other heads or so.

metadata.sub_sub_section: 3.4.2|How to Execute Nozzle Shaft Blow Manually

content:
continues, then the nozzle left on the air-blow station might interfere with other heads or so.

YRM20/YRM20DL performs the missing nozzle detection by taking image of nozzles with side-view

cameras. This check occurs at Z-axis UP completion following a shaft air-blow operation.

If a missing nozzle is detected, an error displays and all axes are stopped.

metadata.sub_sub_section: 3.4.2|How to Execute Nozzle Shaft Blow Manually

content:
3.4.3 Automatic Nozzle Shaft Blow Procedure

The nozzle shaft blow can be automatically performed at the desired timing.

The following is the setting procedure.

Step 1 Press the [machine] button.

The “VmSpec” screen appears.

Step 2 Select the “Schedule Specification”.

Select the “Schedule Specification” on the left side of the “VmSpec” screen.

NOTE

The “Schedule Specification” is an item set up in the machine that requires the authorization at the administrator level.

Step 3 Set the nozzle shaft blow.

1. Select the “Shaft Cleaning Blow” from the Check Item drop-down list.

2. Mark the checkbox of the “Check Execution”.

3. (If the machine has the nozzle station) Select the nozzle for nozzle shaft blow from

3. (If the machine has the nozzle station) Select the nozzle for nozzle shaft blow from

“All nozzle” or “Only Using nozzle” specified by the board data.

4. Set the “Executive Condition” and the “Cycle Condition”.

5. Press the save icon on the upper left corner of the screen to save the settings.

6. Press the close icon [x] on the upper right corner of the screen to exit the “VmSpec” screen.

Setting automatic nozzle shaft blow

“VmSpec” screen

Path Image Setting automatic nozzle shaft blow VmSpec screen : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Operator_Manual/Head_Unit/Chapter_1_Unit_Names_and_Functionsfront_3_3.4_3.4.3_Setting_automatic_nozzle_shaft_blow_VmSpec_screen.png

Step 4 Reload the board data.

The automatic nozzle shaft blow setting will be reflected after reloading the board data.

“Executive Condition” and “Cycle Condition” of nozzle shaft blow

Executive Condition

| Executive Condition | Operation |
| --- | --- |
| None | The automatic nozzle shaft blow is not performed. |
| Power On | The nozzle shaft blow is performed after powering on the machine. |
| Power Off | The nozzle shaft blow is performed before powering off the machine. |
| Reset | The nozzle shaft blow is performed at the time of resetting. |
| Start Run | The nozzle shaft blow is performed when starting up the automatic  operation. |
| Lot Start + Auto Running | The nozzle shaft blow is performed at the time of starting up the  automatic operation after loading the board data according to the set  cycle condition. |
| Only Auto Running | The nozzle shaft blow is performed according to the set cycle condition. |
Cycle Condition

| Cycle Condition | Operation |
| --- | --- |
| None | No cycle condition applies. |
| Minute Unit | The nozzle shaft blow is performed according to the pre-set time  interval (minutes). |
| Every Day | The nozzle shaft blow is performed at the pre-set time of every day  when the machine is in the automatic operation. |
| Every Week | The nozzle shaft blow is performed at the pre-set time of the day of the  week when the machine is in the automatic operation. |

NOTE

Setting the multiple times is available with the “Multi Interval Setting”.

NOTE

Setting the multiple times is available with the “Multi Interval Setting”.

3.4.4 Shaft Blow Dump of Microminiature Components

Regarding to disposal of microminiature components less than 0603 size on this machine, if some components

or dust are recognized at checking after disposing operation, the air-blow station continues the shaft blow

dump. The target components for the shaft blow dump are determined by the following three settings.

1. The machine is equipped with the air-blow station.

2. The function of the shaft blow dump is set to “Use” in [machine Data] > [Mechanical] > [Position],

and “Dump Size” and “Blow Timer” are appropriately set.

3. The size of the component to be disposed of is less than the setting value in 2.

Additionally, if “B: Bring Back Check” is set to “Use” on the [Parts] > [Side View] tab screen, the side-view

cameras will be used for the check after the disposal operation, and if it is set to “Not Use” on a machine with

the HM, FM, or LM head unit, the vacuum pressure check will be used.

the HM, FM, or LM head unit, the vacuum pressure check will be used.

3.5 Vacuum Pump for RM Head Unit

3.5.1 Vacuum Pump for RM Head Unit

RM head unit generates vacuum for component pick-up by vacuum pump.

The vacuum pump is installed at the inside of machine rear panel.

The vacuum pump located at rear left of machine, viewed from front, works for front head unit, and the

other, for rear head unit (the figure below is viewed from machine rear).

The HM, FM, and LM head units generate vacuum for component pick-up by ejector in the head unit.

4 Component Supply Section

4.1 machine Layout

There are several machine layout patterns, depending on the beam type, feeder unit type, and with or

without Tray Component Supply Unit.

feeder exchange carriage specification

YRM20 with feeder exchange carriage has four carriage set positions and can be attached the feeder

exchange carriage up to four units. Also, each one of carriages can be attached the feeders up to 32

pieces. The carriage set positions are called F1, F2, R1, and R2, as shown in the figure below.

When the carriage is attached to F1, the feeder set position numbers are 1-32; when set to F2, 33-64;

when set to R1, 101-132; and when set to R2, 133-164.

Fixed feeder plate specification

YRM20 with fixed feeder plate has four positions for 32-reel fixed feeder plate as same as YRM20 with

feeder exchange carriage.

For 32-reel fixed feeder plate x four units, the feeder set position numbers are the same as YRM20 with

feeder exchange carriage. For 32-reel fixed feeder plate x two units, the feeder set position numbers are

33-64 for F2 and 133-164 for R2.

feeder unit and Tray Component Supply Unit specification

Tray Component Supply Unit (eATS30, cATS10R, sATS30R, or sATS30NSR) can be attached to the set

position F1 and R1. There are three machine layouts for Tray Component Supply Unit, front and rear

(F1 and R1), only front (F1), and only rear (R1). You can select a feeder exchange carriage or a fixed

feeder plate as the feeder unit.

4.2 Supplying Component Tape

4.2.1 Feeder Exchange Carriage

The feeder exchange carriage (hereinafter referred to as carriage) enables to change the multiple feeders

at once by changing the feeder exchange carriage as unit, which has been attached components.

The feeder exchange carriage can be set ZS feeder, ZSR feeder and auto loading feeder. Additionally, using

ZS feeder and ZSR feeder enables “Non-stop feeder change” that can change feeders without stopping

automatic operation.

4.2.3 Detaching/Attaching Upper Cover

The upper cover may be detached during setting-up machine or maintenance.

The following describes the procedure of attaching/detaching the upper cover.

Detaching Upper Cover

1. Pull frontward the cover locks located at both sides of upper cover.

2. Open the upper cover 30 degrees upward by hand.

3. Pull out front-and-upward while supporting the upper cover with both hands.

Detaching upper cover

Path Image Detaching upper cover : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Operator_Manual/Component_Supply_Section/Chapter_1_Unit_Names_and_Functionsfront_4_4.2_4.2.3_Detaching_upper_cover.png

Attaching Upper Cover

1. Open upper cover end plate manually and hold position of upper cover guide section and end plate

as illustrated below (angle 30 degrees).

2. Insert upper cover into machine at an angle of 30 degrees. At this time, make far end pins and

second far end pins, located at both sides of upper cover, fit into their guides.

second far end pins, located at both sides of upper cover, fit into their guides.

3. Close the upper cover. When it is locked, the cover locks on both sides of it will make a clicking

sound.

Attaching upper cover

Temporary Placing of Upper Cover and Precautions

The upper cover can be placed temporarily onto handles of a feeder exchange carriage.

The upper cover can be placed temporarily onto handles of a feeder exchange carriage.

Also, a cover identification label attached to upper cover carries machine serial number and number of

carriage set position.

The upper cover is not compatible with other carriage set positions or other machines, as its guide

position has been adjusted for its machine when the machine was assembled before shipping.

Therefore, use the upper cover at the machine/carriage set position indicated on its identification label.

Temporary placing the upper cover

Moreover, sensors are equipped to detect upper cover at carriage set position of machine.

The upper cover end plate detection sensor detects attaching fault of cover end plate, and the upper

cover safety switch detects whether the cover closes correctly.

When even one fault is detected by these two sensors, automatic operation cannot start.

4.4 Non-Stop Feeder Change

The YRM20/YRM20DL supports the Non-stop feeder change of ZS/ZSR feeders.

Activating the “ZSF Nonstop Parts Supply” setting allows you to exchange the tape feeders that meet the

removal conditions (explained in “feeder removal conditions” on the next page) without stopping the

machine.

Additionally, when the setting is activated, the tape feeders which are not used for component mounting

can be removed or inserted even during operation.

Summary of Non-stop feeder change conditions

|   | “ZSF Nonstop Parts Supply” setting is enabled | “ZSF Nonstop Parts Supply”  setting is disabled |
| --- | --- | --- |
|   | Feeders  in use | Feeders that meet  removal conditions | Feeders  not in use | Feeders  in use | Feeders  not in use |
| Mounter in operation | Not available | Available | Available | Not available | Not available |

CAUTION

When pulling the feeder, make sure to pull it completely and insert it after cutting the carrier tape. If pulling the feeder incompletely and insert it, the carrier tape is raised and it may interfere with the head.

NOTE

The fixed feeder plate does not support Non-stop feeder change.

Non-stop feeder change setting

Setting non-stop feeder change

[machine Information] > [Installation Setting] screen

Path Image [machine Information] > [Installation Setting] screen : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Operator_Manual/Component_Supply_Section/Chapter_1_Unit_Names_and_Functionsfront_4_4.4_Setting_nonstop_feeder_machine_Information_Installation_Setting_screen.png

operation with SS feeder

YRM20/YRM20DL can use SS feeder.

But since it is necessary to open the safety cover and upper cover for changing SS feeders, non-stop

feeder change function is not available.

feeder removal conditions

1. When Setting the “Skip Retry”

feeder removal conditions

1. When Setting the “Skip Retry”

If setting the skip retry, the parts of the feeder occurring the parts run-out will be mounted at the end

and other normal parts will be mounted prior to them. At this time the message “Ea30151 Parts

empty (Continue to Run)” will be displayed on the screen and the corresponding feeder can be

removed. The LED of the removable feeder glows yellow.

2. When pressing the [feeder remove] button

If activating the non-stop feeder change setting, the [feeder remove] button will be displayed on the

“Monitor”–“production” screen. The message “Ea30152 Ready to remove the feeder.” will be

displayed by selecting any feeder and pressing the [feeder remove] button. Then the feeder will be

removable. Same as the skip retry setting, the selected feeder parts will be mounted at the end and

other normal parts will be mounted prior to them.

NOTE

other normal parts will be mounted prior to them.

NOTE

Regarding both cases above, if the parts of the removed feeder are mounted before completing the parts refill, an error occurs and the machine stops.

3. When setting the alternative component function

If setting the alternative component function, the feeder occurred the parts run-out will be replaced

to the other feeder that the alternative component function is set and it continues to mount. At this

time the message “Ea30151 Parts empty (Continue to Run)” will be displayed on the screen and the

corresponding feeder can be removed. The LED of the removable feeder glows yellow.

Additionally, if refilling components to the removed feeder and setting it to the machine again, the

component supply is changed to the feeder that has been set again.

feeder removal condition 1: “Skip Retry” Setting

Step 1 Open the [oard] > [board] tab screen.

Press the [board] button and select the [board] tab.

Step 2 Set the “Skip Retry”.

Press the [board] button and select the [board] tab.

Step 2 Set the “Skip Retry”.

Select “Use” from the “i: Skip Retry” drop-down list.

Step 1 Select the source component.

Step 1 Select the source component.

1. Press the [Parts] button and press the [Assistant] button on the “Parts” screen to display the edit

panel on the lower area of its screen.

2. Select the source component from the component data list in the upper grid.

Selecting alternative component

Step 3 Copy and paste the component data.

Select an empty row in the component data list and press the [OwPaste] button. For example, paste

the data onto data rows No. 19 and No. 20 to use two feeders as alternative components.

Copy and paste the component data

Step 4 Enter feeder Set No. for the copied component.

1. Press the [Assistant] button again to return to the original “Parts” screen.

Press the [Pick] tab.

2. Enter a desired set position number to the “feeder Set No.” field for the component copied in

Step 3. It must be a number that does not duplicate other feeder set positions.

Entering feeder Set No.

[Parts] > [Pick] tab screen

Path Image Entering feeder Set No. : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Operator_Manual/Component_Supply_Section/Chapter_1_Unit_Names_and_Functionsfront_4_4.4_Feeder_Set_No.png

Step 5 Specify the alternative component numbers.

1. Press the [Option] tab.

2. Select data No. 6 in the component data list and enter “19” for the “A: Alternative Parts” field in

the [Option] tab.

3. Select data No. 19 and enter “20” for the “A: Alternative Parts”.

4. Select data No. 20 and enter “6” for the “A: Alternative Parts”.

4. Select data No. 20 and enter “6” for the “A: Alternative Parts”.

The settings above mean that the alternative component for No. 6 is No. 19, that for No. 19 is No. 20

and that for No. 20 is No. 6, just like making a loop as an alternative component group. Detach No. 6

feeder from machine while it is substituted by No. 19, set new components and attach again the

reloaded feeder to No. 6 position of machine. When the reloaded feeder is set to No. 6, components

are supplied from feeder No. 6 automatically.

CAUTION

Data No. for alternative components must make a loop.

5 Conveyor

5.1 Conveyor Unit

The following describes the conveyor unit that carries-in and clamps a board.

5.1.1 Dual-Stage Type

conveyor unit

Dual-stage (Example: Right-to-left flow)

Path Image conveyor unit Dual-stage : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Operator_Manual/Conveyor/Chapter_1_Unit_Names_and_Functionsfront_5_5.1_5.1.1_Conveyor_unit_Dualstage_Right_to_left_flow.png

1. Standby stopper

If a board is on the mounting position already, the next board carried into the conveyor will wait in this

stopper position.

2. Mounting stage 1 main stopper

This is a board stopper in the mounting position on the Mounting stage 1.

A board carried into the conveyor will be in contact with this stopper and stop.

3. Mounting stage 2 main stopper

These are board stoppers in the mounting position on the Mounting stage 2.

There are two main stoppers for the Mounting stage 2, which are used depending on the board sizes.

4. Exit stopper

If there is no board request signal from a downstream machine, the board with components mounted

will wait in this stopper position.

5. Push-up plate

6. Push-up pin

will wait in this stopper position.

5. Push-up plate

6. Push-up pin

Arrange the push-up pins onto the push-up plate, depending on the specifications and shape of a board

used for component mounting. When a board comes into the mounting position, the push-up plate will

raise and the push-up pins will hold the board by pushing it up from the bottom.

7. board hold plate

8. board clamp plate (clamp board assembly)

When a board comes into the mounting position, the board clamp plate will also raise.

The board clamp plate will clamp the board by pushing its edges up against the board hold plates.

Adjust the positions of board hold plates depending on the specifications and shape of a board.

9. Pin push-up prevention sensor

When the push-up plate is being raised, this sensor detects that the conveyor frame is being pushed up

even if a push-up pin or other object is located between the push-up plate and the conveyor frame, and

stops the push-up plate being raised.

NOTE

stops the push-up plate being raised.

NOTE

The whole mounting stage 2 of conveyor unit of dual stage machine moves back and forth (U-axis).

The mounting time can be shortened by the above motion as the mounting position, component pick-up position and head unit come close each other.

5.1.2 Single-Lane Type

conveyor unit

Single-lane (Example: Right-to-left flow)

Path Image conveyor unit Single-lane : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Operator_Manual/Conveyor/Chapter_1_Unit_Names_and_Functionsfront_5_5.1_5.1.2_Conveyor_unit_Singlelane_Right_to_left_flow.png

1. Standby stopper

If a board is on the mounting position already, the next board carried into the conveyor will wait in this

stopper position.

2. Main stopper

This is a board stopper for the mounting position.

A board carried into the conveyor will be in contact with this stopper and stop.

3. Exit stopper

If there is no board request signal from a downstream machine, the board with components mounted

will wait in this stopper position.

4. Push-up plate

5. Push-up pin

Arrange the push-up pins onto the push-up plate, depending on the specifications and shape of a board

used for component mounting. When a board comes into the mounting position, the push-up plate will

used for component mounting. When a board comes into the mounting position, the push-up plate will

raise and the push-up pins will hold the board by pushing it up from the bottom.

6. board hold plate

7. board clamp plate (clamp board assembly)

When a board comes into the mounting position, the board clamp plate will also raise.

The board clamp plate will clamp the board by pushing its edges up against the board hold plates.

Adjust the positions of board hold plates depending on the specifications and shape of a board.

8. Pin push-up prevention sensor

When the push-up plate is being raised, this sensor detects that the conveyor frame is being pushed up

even if a push-up pin or other object is located between the push-up plate and the conveyor frame, and

stops the push-up plate being raised.

5.1.3 Dual-Lane Type

conveyor unit

Dual-lane (Example: Right-to-left flow)

Path Image conveyor unit Dual-lane : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Operator_Manual/Conveyor/Chapter_1_Unit_Names_and_Functionsfront_5_5.1_5.1.3_Conveyor_unit_Duallane_Right_to_left_flow.png

NOTE

The Dual-lane type machines do not use stoppers such as main stopper and standby stopper to transfer boards. boards are transferred with control by sensors.

1. Push-up pin

Arrange the push-up pins onto the push-up plate, depending on the specifications and shape of a board

used for component mounting. When a board comes into the mounting position, the push-up plate will

raise and the push-up pins will hold the board by pushing it up from the bottom.

2. Push-up plate

Arrange the push-up pins on this plate. This plate moves up and down to support a board from the

bottom. It is installed in two locations per lane, for a total of four locations.

3. board hold plate

3. board hold plate

The following two types of board clamp plates are attached on the conveyor rails.

• Triangle shaped board hold plate: Movable to fit the size of a board

• Square shaped board hold plate: Fixed

CAUTION

Note that if a board is fixed with no board hold plates positioned on top of the board, the board may be lifted at an angle and collide with the head.

CAUTION

Square shaped board hold plates are installed so that they are positioned on top of a board, regardless of the board size. Therefore, do not change their positions.

4. board clamp plate (interlocking with push-up plate)

This plate moves up as the push-up plate moves up.

These plates are used to push up both sides of a board, and the board will be fixed by sandwiching it

between these plates and board hold plates.

Adjust the positions of board hold plates depending on the specifications and shape of a board.

5. Pin detection sensor

5. Pin detection sensor

This sensor is installed on each of the two conveyor rails inside the conveyor unit in pairs, one for

emitting beam and one for receiving beam. (One pair per lane, two pairs in total.)

When the two movable conveyor rails that are shown in the center of the figure move, these sensors will

detect the presence or absence of a push-up pin. If a push-up pin is detected, an error will be reported.

6 Recognition Unit

This machine uses a fiducial camera to recognize marks and a multi-view camera, a scan camera, and a

side-view camera to recognize components as the recognition units.

The multi-view camera and coplanarity check camera (option) are equipped at base side of machine to

recognize components. These devices vary according to the head specification.

6.1 Fiducial Camera

The RM, HM, FM, and LM head units are equipped with this camera at side. This is used to recognize

fiducial marks and to perform teaching for components mounting position. The head unit has two fiducial

cameras at both sides in order to extend the sight (double fiducial cameras).

Fiducial camera

RM, HM, FM, and LM head units

Path Image RM head unit :

Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Operator_Manual/Recognition_Unit/Chapter_1_Unit_Names_and_Functionsfront_6_6.1_Fiducial_camera_RM_head_unit.png

Path Image HM head unit : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Operator_Manual/Recognition_Unit/Chapter_1_Unit_Names_and_Functionsfront_6_6.1_Fiducial_camera_HM_head_unit.png

Path Image FM head unit : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Operator_Manual/Recognition_Unit/Chapter_1_Unit_Names_and_Functionsfront_6_6.1_Fiducial_camera_FM_head_unit.png
Path Image LM head unit : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Operator_Manual/Recognition_Unit/Chapter_1_Unit_Names_and_Functionsfront_6_6.1_Fiducial_camera_LM_head_unit.png

6.2 Scan Camera

The HM head unit is equipped with this camera at bottom. After components are picked up, this camera

moves left and right to recognize the picked component while the head unit moves to the mounting

position. This has also the side-view function as standard.

Scan camera
Path Image Scan camera : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Operator_Manual/Recognition_Unit/Chapter_1_Unit_Names_and_Functionsfront_6_6.2_Scan_camera.png

6.3 Side-View Camera

The RM and FM head units are equipped with this camera at bottom. This camera takes from side the

images of component being picked-up by nozzle. The RM head unit is equipped four side-view cameras and

the rotary rotates after picked-up component to move the nozzle picking-up component in front of the

nearest camera and then component recognition is performed.

Side-view camera

RM and FM head units

RM head unit
Path Image RM head unit : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Operator_Manual/Recognition_Unit/Chapter_1_Unit_Names_and_Functionsfront_6_6.3_RM_head_unit_side_view_camera.png

FM head unit
Path Image FM head unit : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Operator_Manual/Recognition_Unit/Chapter_1_Unit_Names_and_Functionsfront_6_6.3_FM_head_unit_side_view_camera.png

6.4 Side-View Function (for Scan Camera/Side-View Camera)

The functions below can be used by Side-view camera and Scan camera to recognize components and

nozzles horizontally.

Pick-up error detection function

• Simple mode

Detects component pick-up errors, thus preventing missed mountings.

operation can continue without interruption even when nozzles are changed due to nozzle washing,

etc.

• Detailed mode

Detects component pick-up errors, thus preventing missed mountings.

Vertical, horizontal, slanting, etc., pick-up error judgments are made based on the user-specified

component thickness tolerance.

Soiled nozzle detection function

If a component is recognized as “present” at component recognition, but as “absent” by the side-view

function, this is judged a “soiled nozzle” condition, and a warning message displays.

This enables the user to better identify the best time to wash a nozzle.

Component discard operation skip function

A discard operation skip occurs if the side-view function makes a “component absent” judgment.

A discard operation skip occurs if the side-view function makes a “component absent” judgment.

This reduces wasted operation when a component has not been picked up, resulting in a lower tact.

Component return detection function

Detects a component which is still on the nozzle tip after it should have been mounted or discarded.

Upside down check function

Checks (at recognition processing) for components which have been picked up in an upside down

posture. This function also checks to see if the picked-up component size can be contained within

side-view camera's field of view.

An error message displays if the component is recognized as being upside down, or if its size cannot be

contained within side-view camera's field of view.

This function does not apply to components which have upper-half leads or for components which have

no side-face leads.

TIP

For details regarding the side-view function's parameters, refer to the Programming Manual.

6.5 Multi-View Camera

The multi-view camera recognizes components when mounting components with RM, FM, or LM head unit

or when components are too big to be recognized with the scan camera on HM head unit. (See the following

NOTE for component sizes.)

This is installed on either or both of front and rear depending on the head unit selection or its specification.

Multi-view camera

Path Image Multi-view camera : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Operator_Manual/Recognition_Unit/Chapter_1_Unit_Names_and_Functionsfront_6_6.5_Multi_view_camera.png

NOTE

The maximum sizes of components that the scan camera equipped to HM head unit can recognize are as below. When a component size is bigger than this, a multi-view camera is required to recognize it.

• 12 mm in length and width, 6.5 mm in height

Here describes the maximum recognition size and allowed component height for each head unit.

|   | Maximum recognition size | Allowed component height |
| --- | --- | --- |
| RM head unit | 12 x 12 mm | 6.5 mm or lower |
| HM head unit (Multi-view camera) | 55 x 100 mm | 15 mm or lower |
| HM head unit (Scan camera) | 12 x 12 mm | 6.5 mm or lower |
| FM head unit | 55 x 100 mm | 30 mm or lower |
| LM head unit | 90 x 139 mm | 40 mm or lower |

TIP

See the specification sheet for the details of maximum recognition size of connector or odd-form components.

TIP

The allowable component heights for the LM head unit vary depending on the conveyor specifications.

See the specification sheet for the details.

6.5.1 Coplanarity Check Camera (Option)

The multi-view camera with a coplanarity checker can be selected as an option for HM, FM, and LM head

units. In addition to the multi camera recognizing components, by using the coplanarity checker to

recognize components diagonally, it measures lead linearity and coplanarity of QFP/SOP leads or BGA

bumps at high speeds, then determines “pass/fail”.

Coplanarity check camera

Path Image Coplanarity check camera : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Operator_Manual/Recognition_Unit/Chapter_1_Unit_Names_and_Functionsfront_6_6.5_6.5.1_Coplanarity_check_camera.png

The coplanarity checker has the following two functions:

Coplanarity check

Inspects uniformity of the lead bottom against the seating plane of components having wire leads or

solder balls so that the fault mounting due to such as leads floating are prevented.

Component recognition height check

Prevents lead components from being mounted in an inverted position.

8 Other Options

This section describes the ionizer and the BACKUP UNIT (Uninterruptible Power Supply) as options else

for this machine.

8.1 Ionizer

The ionizers are installed to defuse the static electricity.

Note that its performance and capability for removing static electricity depends on the operating

environment or the material and shape of the target items, so they are not guaranteed.

The ionizer of this machine is installed behind the machine safety cover. It faces around the component

pick-up position of feeders when shipped from the factory. The installation angle can be changed according

to the specifications of boards and components.

Ionizer

Path Image ionzier : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Operator_Manual/Other_Options/Chapter_1_Unit_Names_and_Functions_8_8.1_Ionizer.png

Ionizer indication

| POWER | The green LED lights up when the electric power is supplied normally. |
| --- | --- |
| RUN | The green LED stays on during the normal operation. |
| ALARM | The red LED lights up if the discharge needle has deteriorated or an inner unit/device is  experiencing an error. The machine main body also generates an alarm. |
| CLEANING TIMER | When the duration time set up by operating the rotary switch of “T.SELECT” has expired, the  “CLEANING” yellow LED lights up. Pressing the “RESET” button makes the yellow LED go out.  *Note that this timer is not set up at the time of shipping from the factory. |

TIP

See the manufacturer’s operation manual for the detailed specifications of the ionizer.

8.2 BACKUP UNIT (Uninterruptible Power Supply Unit)

The BACKUP UNIT is a device that supplies electric power to the machine for a certain period of time even if

the electric power supplied to the machine is cut off due to a power outage, momentary power interruption or

instantaneous power drop.

Through setting the BACKUP UNIT, the control box and the conveyor I/O board will be supplied with backup

power even in the event of a power outage. Therefore, the shutdown process can be performed safely

without damaging the board data in the machine.

BACKUP UNIT’s location

The combination of the control unit and the battery unit is called “BACKUP UNIT”.

It is located in the base on the back of the machine. The 480-watt type BACKUP UNIT is located in the

front, the 960-watt type BACKUP UNIT is located in the back in the base.

BACKUP UNIT’s location
Path Image BACKUP UNIT’s location : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Operator_Manual/Other_Options/Chapter_1_Unit_Names_and_Functions_8_8.2_BACKUP_UNIT_location.png

NOTE

NOTE

The combination of the control unit and battery unit is called “BACKUP UNIT”.

TIP

For details on handling the BACKUP UNIT and replacing the battery unit, see the “YRM20/YRM20DL Option Manual”.

1 Before Operation

The following explains how to cancel emergency stop and clear errors. Read before operating the machine.

Cautions during machine operation

• Do not turn off the compressed air during operation. The machine may malfunction, as pneumatic

devices are not correctly controlled.

• Before beginning maintenance, switch off the air-supply as needed. Before that, if there is the

residual pressure releasing valve, make sure to open it to release the residual pressure.

Cautions during power outages

If a power outage (blackout) occurs during automatic machine operation, always turn the main power

switch off to prevent faulty operation or machine damage after power has been restored. Also remove

the boards that remain in the machine.

1.1 Canceling Emergency Stop

Follow these steps to cancel emergency stop.

Step 1 Release the emergency stop button.

When the emergency stop button is pressed, turn it clockwise to release it.

Step 2 Check safety.

Before continuing the procedure, check the surrounding area for safety.

Step 3 Press the [READY] button.

Pressing the [READY] button on the operation display turns on the servomotors.

CAUTION

The [READY] button is enabled only when the [ACTIVE] button next to it is active.

[READY] button

Path Image [READY] button : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Operator_Manual/Other_Options/Chapter_2_Basic_Operation_1_1.1_Ready_button.png

Step 4 Check the signal light and screen display.

Check that the red or white lamp of the signal light is off and the emergency stop sign on the top

left of the operation screen (that is, in status area) is now off.

1.2 Clearing Errors

If an error occurs a buzzer sounds and a warning screen appears. To clear the error, use the following steps.

Step 1 Turn off the buzzer.

Press the [ERROR CLEAR] button on the operation display or the [BUZZER OFF] button on the error

screen to turn off the buzzer.

Step 2 Check the cause of the error.

Possible causes are displayed on the lower part in the error screen, so check or make a note of the

description.

Step 3 Clear the error screen.

Press the [ERROR CLEAR] button again or the [ERROR CLEAR] button on the error screen to clear

the error screen.

Step 4 Check the signal light and screen display.

Check that the yellow or blue lamp of the signal light is off and the error message on the left of the

status area in the operation screen is now off.

Error screen

1.4 Switching Display Language

YRM20/YRM20DL supports English (EN), Japanese (JA), German (DE), Chinese (ZH), Korean (KO), and

Vietnamese (VI) as its display languages.

The display language switches by pressing the language switch button located at the top right of screen,

according to the contents of “Language switch setting” set in advance. For example, when “English”,

“German”, and “Japanese” are set in this sequence for “Language Switch setting”, the displayed language

will be switched as following by each pressing the [Language Switch] button; English (EN) > German (DE) >

Japanese (JA) > English (EN)...

NOTE

The “Language Switch” can be performed at any time regardless of operator level, machine status or displayed screen.

Switching display language

Path Image Switching display language : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Operator_Manual/Before_Operation/Chapter_2_Basic_Operation_1_1.4_Switching_display_language.png

The “Language switch setting” can be set by the following procedure.

Step 1 Press the [Software Setting] button at bottom right of “Setup” screen.

Step 2 Display the “Massage Language Setting” screen.

Select the [View] tab of the software “Setting” screen and press the [Message Language] button to

display the “Message Language Setting” screen.

“Languages to be used” and “Display order of languages to be used” can be set at the “Message

Language Setting” screen.

2. Change the order of languages by selecting language and pressing the arrow buttons displayed

at right.

changed setting will be reflected.
