2 Operation Screen and Buttons

The basic configuration and operation methods of the operation screens are explained in this section.

NOTE

Standard specification machines do not have a keyboard or touchpad, so all operations are performed using the touch panel. A dialog box will appear when entering parameters, so use the touch pen to operate and enter parameters.

2.1 Basic Configuration of Operation Screen

The operation screen consists of “Status area”, “Main menu button area” and “Submenu button and

parameter area” as shown below.

Example of screen configuration

Screen for Dual-lane

Path Image Screen for Dual-lane : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Operator_Manual/Operation_Screen_and_Buttonsn/Chapter_2_Basic_Operation_2_2.1_Screen_configuration_Dual_lane.png

Areas on screen

| Status area | From left to right, the current machine status (such as “AUTO.”, “ERROR”, and “SAFE.”),  the name of the selected board data, the number of boards produced, and the operator's  name currently logged in are displayed.  When both lanes are used for production on the YRM20DL, the board name and the  number of boards produced for each lane are displayed on two rows.  The “Updated” appears during editing the board data and disappears after saving the  edited data.   Moreover, the mount compilation rate per each mounting table is displayed in graph form  at the background. See the next section “Status area details” for details. |
| --- | --- |
| Main menu button area 1 | Shows the main menu buttons used to operate the machine. The submenu button and  parameter area will change according to the selected main menu button. |
| Main menu button area 2 | Shows the menu buttons used to call up auxiliary functions of the machine. |
| Main menu button area 3 | Shows the “power off” button to turn off the machine and the “language switch” button  to switch display languages. |
| Main menu button area 4 | Appears only on YRM20DL. Use it to switch the lanes during Parallel Lanes mounting. |
| Submenu button and   parameter area | Displays the submenu buttons and parameters for machine operation and data setting.  This area will change according to the selected main menu button. |

2.1.1 Status Area Details

Examples of automatic operation, error, and emergency stop status

Path Image Status Area Details : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Operator_Manual/Operation_Screen_and_Buttons/Chapter_2_Basic_Operation_2_2.1_2.1.1_status_Area_detail.png

Path Image Display for Dual-lane : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Operator_Manual/Operation_Screen_and_Buttons/Chapter_2_Basic_Operation_2_2.1_2.1.1_status_Area_detail_dual_lane.png

• Current production quantity

Displays “Current production quantity/Scheduled production quantity”.

• Mount compilation rate display

The “Mount compilation rate” is displayed in graph form at the background of status area when

starting automatic operation. The mount status per one board under production/per each mounting

stage can be checked here. The color of “Mount compilation rate” graph varies depending on

machine status.

machine status.

Mount compilation rate
Path Image Mount compilation rate : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Operator_Manual/Operation_Screen_and_Buttons/Chapter_2_Basic_Operation_2_2.1_2.1.1_Mount_compilation_rate.png

NOTE

The graph of mount compilation rate is displayed using the values calculated with the following formula.

Mount compilation rate (%) = (The number mount is completed / The number of all mounts) × 100

Note that the mount point where the mounting is not performed due to the bad mark for instance is not included in the mount completion rate. Therefore, the final mount compilation rate may not be 100%. Additionally, the skipped mount point is not included in the calculation.

2.1.2 Buttons and Parameter Input Boxes

Various types of buttons, selection tabs and parameter input boxes are used on the operation screen.

Example of operation screen

“Mark” screen

Path Image “Mark” screen : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Operator_Manual/Operation_Screen_and_Buttons/Chapter_2_Basic_Operation_2_2.1_2.1.2_operation_screen_Mark_screen.png

1. Scroll bar and button (vertical/horizontal)

Use the scroll bars or arrow buttons to see hidden items in the data number list or parameter list.

2. operation button

Press these buttons to open the next operation screen or dialog box.

3. Line up/down button

Use these buttons to move the cursor up or down through the data number list or parameter list.

4. Parameter input box

Select, enter or edit parameters here. When the keyboard is used, double-click on a parameter input box

to enter or edit the data.

To operate the touch panel for data entry, press the corresponding [Edit] buttons on the right side of the

screen to have the edit box pop up.

screen to have the edit box pop up.

5. Selection tab

Select these tabs to switch the parameter input screens.

6. Assistant screen

Shows an illustration or information useful for parameter input or editing. Alphabet characters shown in

the parameter list and in the illustration on this screen correspond to each other.

7. Capture button

Captures the displayed image. The captured data (JPEG format) is stored in the D:\ScreenShot folder

(maximum folder size: approx. 10MB), with a file name consisting of the date and time.

When a USB flash drive is inserted into the machine’s USB port and system backup is performed, a

“ScreenShot” folder will be created in the root of the USB flash drive to acquire the captured data stored

in the machine. (The captured data stored in the machine will be moved to the USB flash drive.)

CAUTION

• When saving data in a USB flash drive, make sure to use the USB flash drive designated by YAMAHA.

• If you specify the any other destination to save the data on the Software Setting screen (Select [Setup] > [Software Setting] > [Information] > [Screen Shot Setting]), the captured data cannot be saved in the USB flash drive even by executing System backup.

2.2 “Setup” Screen

This section describes the operation buttons displayed on the “Setup” screen.

“Setup” screen

Path Image For Dual-stage : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Operator_Manual/Operation_Screen_and_Buttons/Chapter_2_Basic_Operation_2_2.2_setup_screen_Dual_stage.png

Path Image For Dual-lane (YRM20DL) : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Operator_Manual/Operation_Screen_and_Buttons/Chapter_2_Basic_Operation_2_2.2_setup_screen_dual_lane_YRM20DL.png

|   | Button name | Function |
| --- | --- | --- |
| 1 | Origin | Move all the axes other than the W-axis of the machine to their respective origins. |
| 2 | Warm Up | Warms up the machine. Specifying the desired time is available. |
| 3 | Cycle Stop | Stops the machine without flowing a mounted board to downstream. |
| 4 | Conveyout Stop | Stops machine operation after mounting components on all boards on the conveyor and  transferring them to the downstream machine. |
| 5 | Halfway Continue | Resumes mounting components on the board that reset the suspended machine operation  due to an error. See “1.13 Resuming operation from stopped Point” in Chapter 3 for more  details. |
| 6 | TrayCnt | Displays the number of tray components that have been used. |
| 7 | Feed Bulk | This button is operable only when using the bulk feeder (custom-made).  It is not used in normal operation. |
| 8 | Required Parts | Displays the component types and feeder positions that are set up for the production to be  started. |
| 9 | Step | Temporarily stops the machine at a specific position, for example, during initial component  mounting, test mounting, or trouble analysis. |
| 10 | Measure Nozzles | The scan camera (side-view camera) acquires the nozzle shape. |
| 11 | Width | Adjusts the conveyor to the board width for production.  It is the same function as the [Width] button of the [Unit] > [conveyor] tab screen. |
| 12 | Tip Cln Check | Checks if nozzle tips are dirty or clogged. |
| 13 | Required Nozzles | Displays a list of nozzles to be used. |
| 14 | Block Skip | This button becomes active when board data with   block distribution performed is loaded.  Pressing this button displays the “Block Skip Utility”   dialog box that allows you to set whether to skip   component mounting in each block.  For more details, refer to “1.13 Resuming operation   from stopped Point” in Chapter 3.  Path Image Block Skip : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Operator_Manual/Operation_Screen_and_Buttons/Chapter_2_Basic_Operation_2_2.2_Block_Skip.png |
| 15 | Mount Position | Moves the conveyor to the mounting position for the back-up pin setup. |
| 16 | Transfer Position | Aligns the conveyor with the transfer position when carrying in the board manually. |
| 17 | Head Pos.  (Rear, Center, Front) | Moves head to the machine rear, center, or front. |
| 18 | History | Saves and deletes production history data. |
| 19 | Software Setting | Sets machine screen display items, adds or deletes operators, and sets passwords. |
| 20 | SW Version Info | Shows version information on application software and system. |
| 21 | Board Explorer | Moves, backs up, restores or copies board data. |
| 22 | Database | Makes a backup of and restores database regarding components required for production and  mark information. Also it can specify the database reference destination. |
| 23 | System Backup | Makes a backup of machine coordinates, accuracy information, option device information  and standard coordinates necessary for machine operation or restores the data using the  backup. |
| 24 | Search Board | Checks for the presence of a board on the conveyor and transfers it to the board transfer  position. By pressing this button, the board moves to a nearby board stop position and stops. |
| 25 | Pos. Check | Checks with the fiducial camera that a board is at the correct position.  The “q: Carried Pos. Check” must be set to “Enable” in the board data. |
| 26 | Convey Board | Displays the “Convey Boards” dialog box.  Select the position and click on the [OK] button to transfer a board to the specified position. |
| 27 | Push Up | Displays the “Conveyor Push Up” dialog box.  Enter a board thickness and click on the [OK] button to lift the push-up stage. |
| 28 | Lane (1 or 2) | On Dual-lane type (YRM20DL), switches the display between “Lane1” and “Lane2”. |

2. [Sensor Tune] button

Tunes the conveyor sensor automatically. It is not required to perform auto tuning during normal

operation. However, it is used in the case where the conveyor width is changed manually or that the

board cannot be detected correctly due to the conveyor sensor malfunction.

CAUTION

Make sure that no board is on the conveyor before tuning the conveyor sensor.

See the Maintenance manual, Chapter 3, “2.3.1 Checking conveyor Sensor Condition and Its operation”.

3 Displaying Production Monitors (“Monitor” Screen)

Press the [Monitor] button and check each monitor screen that appears to confirm the operation status

during the production. The “Monitor” screens includes the tabs [production], [Main], [Vision], [Alignment],

[Retry], and so forth. Select the corresponding tab to check the ongoing mounting information.

3.1 “Production” Tab Screen

This screen graphically shows the information of machines currently producing boards. The machine status

information such as errors that the machine is currently experiencing or work instructions appears on the

lower part of the screens.

[Monitor] > [production] tab screen

Path Image [Monitor] > [production] tab screen : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Operator_Manual/Displaying_Production_Monitors/Chapter_2_Basic_Operation_3_3.1_Monitor_Prod_tab_screen.png

1. Transfer status area

The board that the machine is currently working on is displayed in green.

If an error related to transfer has occurred or if a hazard prediction sensor is activating, the board is

displayed in red.

2. feeder status area

This area displays the feeder set positions that are registered on the [Parts] > [Pick] tab > “A: feeder et

No.” of the board data currently in production. Nothing is displayed for the feeder set positions where

no components are registered. When the feeder is correctly set up and ready for process, it will be

displayed in green. If the feeder is incorrectly set up or experiencing an error, it will be displayed in red.

3. Operating Navigation area (operating instruction message area)

• Operating Navigation instructions

This displays messages with countermeasures for handling errors, operating instructions or

warnings at operating position selected with the “Select Operating Position” drop-down list.

When multiple errors occur, those items with the highest priority for countermeasures will be

displayed in sequence.

To switch to other instruction messages, press the left/right arrow buttons.

• Select Operating Position drop-down list

If the machine is experiencing errors at more than one location, select the location to check from the

drop-down list. Note that the drop-down list shows only positions that require operator task.

NOTE

NOTE

Errors are also displayed in the graphic layout view on the upper part of the screen.

The operating position can be selected by clicking the error area on the graphic layout view. However, the operating position cannot be selected if clicking an area where there are no errors or operating instructions.

• [error detail] button

Pressing this button displays an error message screen that contains detailed information and

countermeasures for the error and operating instruction, or warning displayed in the “Operating

Navigation” area.

• [error clear] button

Press this button after recovering from the error or after handling the operating instruction or

warning displayed in the “Operating Navigation” area. Pressing this button shows that recovery is

complete by following the message in the “Operating Navigation” area, and that automatic operation

can restart. However, automatic operation will not restart if a recovery task is still incomplete.

NOTE

NOTE

If an error has occurred that affects the entire machine, the entire background area will be displayed in blue.

4. Component information display area

Displays basic information on components currently being used in the program (board data) for

production. Data that is causing an error appears in a different color.

• [Option] button

Switches the “part details” area display ON and OFF.

3.2 “Main” Tab Screen

The [Monitor] > [Main] tab screen shows you the real-time production status such as the board count and

cycle time. Displaying this screen during production is handy. All information will be cleared when the board

type is changed.

NOTE

On Dual-lane type (YRM20DL), when both lanes are used, the displayed lane can be switched by pressing the [Lane] button.

[Monitor] > [Main] tab screen

Path Image [Monitor] > [Main] tab screen :  Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Operator_Manual/Displaying_Production_Monitors/Chapter_2_Basic_Operation_3_3.2_Monitor_Main_tab_screen.png

• Start Time

Displays the date and time that the board data currently being produced was changed.

• Estimated End Time

Displays the estimated time of finishing the production.

• Current Time

Displays the current date and time of the system clock time built-in the machine.

• board counter

Displays the current date and time of the system clock time built-in the machine.

• board Counter

The board counter displays the number of boards produced after changing to the current production board data. The board counter counts only the boards completed the mounting. Pressing the button on

the right side allows to switch between “board counter” and “block counter”.

• error rate

The ratio of components discarded due to the pick up error or recognition error occurred from the time of changing to the board data currently producing to present to all the consumed components.

This data is updated when changing the production board.

Number of discarded components

error rate (%) =   一一一一一一一一一一一一一一一一一一一一一一一一一   X 100

Total component consumption

Press the button on the right to switch the display between “error rate” and “Pickup rate (100% minus error rate)”.

• Cycle Time (sec/board)

The cycle time shows the average (seconds/board) of the mounting time per board.

The cycle time shows the average (seconds/board) of the mounting time per board.

The data is updated when the mounting is completed.

Pressing the button on the right allows to switch among “Cycle time”, “Mount CT (cycle time)” and “Transfer CT (cycle time)”. The Cycle Time = Mount CT + Transfer CT.

The Mount CT (cycle time) includes the board mark recognition time such as fiducial bad marks,

component recognition time, mounting time, retry operation time, component discarding time and

nozzle changing times. The stopping time due to an error and the [stop] button is not included.

• Cycle Time (sec/chip) / Cycle Lane (sec/chip)

Shows the time (seconds) to mount one component on the board. This is the time obtained by dividing the time for one sequence from pick-up to mounting by the number of components mounted in that sequence.

Pressing the button on the right switches the indications among “Cycle time (sec/chip)”, “Cycle time

(sec/block)”, “Cycle time (chip/hour)”, “Cycle time (block/hour)” and “Cycle time (board/hour)”.

NOTE

On Dual-lane type (YRM20DL), when switching lanes by pressing the [Lane] button in the lower right corner of the screen, the title will be displayed as “Cycle Lane” for “Lane 1” and “Lane 2” buttons, and “Cycle Total” for “All Lane” button.

• Working Ratio

This is the machine's independent working ratio that is not affected by the status of the upstream and

downstream machines. The following expression calculates the working ratio.

Cumulative mounting time + cumulative transfer time

Working ratio (%) =   一一一一一一一一一一一一一一一一一一一一一一一一一一一一一一一一一一   X 100

(production completion time - setup completion time) - cumulative standby time

• Cumulative mounting time: Total time that head unit is operating

• Cumulative transfer time: Total transfer time (board loading/unloading)

• Cumulative standby time: Total standby time due to upstream or downstream machine

• Cumulative standby time: Total standby time due to upstream or downstream machine

• production completion time: Time changed to next production board

• Setup completion time: Time [START] button was pressed and operation started

• error stop Time

Shows the machine stop time by error.

This is a period of time until the [CLEAR] button is pressed from the error occurrence.

• [Reset] button

This resets the production control information of the production data. It resets each piece of data

displayed on the screen, current production quantity and scheduled production quantity.

The “board counter” value on the Setup screen is also reset when this production data is reset.

3.3 “Vision” Tab Screen

Shows the recognized image of board mark, bad mark or component during the automatic operation.

However, the area shows only the image of the lastly recognized component when the high speed,

continuous component recognition are performed such as by the multi camera.

[Monitor] > [Vision] tab screen

Path Image [Monitor] > [Vision] tab screen : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Operator_Manual/Displaying_Production_Monitors/Chapter_2_Basic_Operation_3_3.3_Monitor_Vision_tab_screen.png

• Table Select, Camera select, head No.

A desired head unit, a camera number and a head number can be selected.

• Parts No.

Inputting a desired parts number makes the list display only its part image. Inputting “0” shows all the

part images.

NOTE

An image is displayed on each left and right of the vision monitor. Select a table, a camera, a head and a parts number for each monitor so that the images can be compared with each other.

• Enlarge/reduce buttons (+, -)

• Enlarge/reduce buttons (+, -)

The recognition result image can be enlarged from 1 to 16 times by pressing the enlarge (+) button. The

image can be reduced to 1/16 by pressing the reduce (-) button. Note that when the image is enlarged,

the smooth component edges may appear jagged, and when reduced, gray sections may appear around

the edges. But this is not a fault.

• Up/down/left/right buttons

The arrow buttons on the upper right and lower right corners of the image screen move the image

vertically. The arrow buttons on the lower left and lower right of the image screen move the image left

to right or right to left. Use these arrow buttons to view a section of the image that is not displayed on

the screen.

• Parts Monitor Mode

This specifies the mode for displaying the components on the monitor during vision recognition.

Depending on the selected item, the recognition results and detection range window will appear on the

image. This monitor mode can also be changed during operation.

• None

Displays the image taken by the camera. The recognition result values are not displayed.

• Vision Result

Displays information such as the recognition results X, Y and R direction position (pixels) and

number of detection leads. Note that the displayed items will differ according to the component

recognition type.

• Detection range

Draws a window for the component detection range. If the component does not fit within the

detection range, it will not be recognized correctly. In this case, check the pick-up state or correct the component data.

• Datum Pos.

Displays a cross cursor indicating the position used as a reference for detecting the lead or

component edge.

• Find Line

Displays the line used for component detection, on a chip component or on the component leads.

If the detection line position is incorrect, adjust the Vision parameters.

• Edges Pos.

If the detection line position is incorrect, adjust the Vision parameters.

• Edges Pos.

Displays a cross cursor at the lead or component edge position.

• Last Pos.

Displays a cross cursor at the center of the component.

• Binary Image

The component is displayed as a binary image.

• Mark Monitor Mode

This specifies the monitor display mode during mark recognition. The recognition results and binary

image will appear on the image according to the selected item. This monitor mode can be changed

during operation.

• None

Displays an image taken by the camera. The recognition result values are not displayed.

• Result

Displays the center position coordinates (pixels) of the detected mark.

• Binary Image

Displays the image taken by the camera as a binary image.

• Grey Image

Displays an image that was processed after being captured by the camera.

The recognition result values are not displayed.

• Search Result

The recognition result values are not displayed.

• Search Result

Draws a line to indicate the boundary between the recognized mark and the background.

• Datum Circle

Draws a mark of the specified diameter from the center of the detected mark.

(Possible only in specific recognition modes.)

• Tangent Circle

Draws an inscribed circle and circumscribed circle from the center of the detected mark.

(Possible only in specific recognition modes.)

• error Image

Displays the error image. (Possible only in specific recognition modes.)

• Individual Data

Displays the individual data when multiple objects are detected.

(Possible only in specific recognition modes.)

• [Img Check] button

Pressing the [Img Check] button calls up the “Vision Check and Save” screen.

The recognized image just before the machine stops due to an error can be checked and saved.

(See “Programming Manual” for more details.)

3.4 “Alignment” Tab Screen

This screen shows a list of the mounting position correction amount following up on component

recognition results during the automatic operation, error numbers and the like.

[Monitor] > [Alignment] tab screen

Path Image [Monitor] > [Alignment] tab screen : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Operator_Manual/Displaying_Production_Monitors/Chapter_2_Basic_Operation_3_3.4_Monitor_Alignment_tab_screen.png

• Table Select

Select a head unit.

• head No.

The head number indicates the component recognition results of one sequence for each head that

starts with the current pick-up operation.

Note that the indication reflects the results after the camera finishes recognizing the image.

• Parts No.

Shows the number of the component picked up by the head and recognized with the camera.

• feeder Set No.

Shows the feeder set number of the component picked up by the head and recognized with the camera.

• X, Y, R

• X, Y, R

Displays the offset amount of each head calculated from the recognition results obtained during

automatic operation. These values are the positional deviation from the center of the nozzle.

• error No.

Shows an error number when the head fails to recognize a component.

3.5 “Retry” Tab Screen

This screen displays the history or the past 100 errors.

If the machine has to retry the operation due to a recognition error or a pick-up error, check this screen.

[Monitor] > [Retry] tab screen

Path Image [Monitor] > [Retry] tab screen : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Operator_Manual/Displaying_Production_Monitors/Chapter_2_Basic_Operation_3_3.5_Monitor_Retry_tab_screen.png

3.6 “Fiducial” Tab Screen

This screen shows the results of recognizing fiducial marks such as “board,block”, “2Point Local” and

“Point” and the correction result.

NOTE

On Dual-lane type (YRM20DL), when both lanes are used, the displayed lane can be switched by pressing the [Lane] button.

[Monitor] > [Fiducial] tab screen

Path Image [Monitor] > [Fiducial] tab screen : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Operator_Manual/Displaying_Production_Monitors/Chapter_2_Basic_Operation_3_3.6_Monitor_Fiducial_tab_screen.png

• Table Select

Select a head unit.

• Fiducial Type

Select the type of the fiducial mark such as “board,block”, “2Point Local” or “Point”.

• Align.X, Y, R

Shows the differences between the fiducial mark recognition results and the input coordinate entered in

the board data with positive or negative values.

• Align.Ratio

Shows the rate of expansion of the board, calculated by using the X, Y and R offset values.

• Result

Shows the recognition results as a “Pass” or “Unfinished”.

• Result

Shows the recognition results as a “Pass” or “Unfinished”.

After the mark has been recognized successfully, the “Unfinished” message will change to “Pass”.

3.7 “Badmark” Tab Screen

This screen shows the recognition results of badmarks such as “board, block” and “Local” badmarks.

NOTE

On Dual-lane type (YRM20DL), when both lanes are used, the displayed lane can be switched by pressing the [Lane] button.

[Monitor] > [Badmark] tab screen

Path Image [Monitor] > [Badmark] tab screen  : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Operator_Manual/Displaying_Production_Monitors/Chapter_2_Basic_Operation_3_3.7_Monitor_Badmark_tab_screen.png

• Table Select

Select a head unit.

• Badmark Type

Select the type of the badmark such as “board,block” or “Local”.

• X, Y

Shows the board data input values (by taking block offset amount into account).

• Result

Makes an “OK” or “NG (means no good)” decision based on the badmark recognition result.

OK: Failed in recognizing a bad mark: Components will be mounted onto a board.

NG: Succeeded in recognizing a bad mark: Components will not be mounted onto a board.

3.8 “Pick Position” Tab Screen

NOTE

Pick-up position offset function will be applied to the components satisfying the following conditions.

• “Correct Mode” on the [machine] > [Specification Information] > [Pick Position Specification] screen is set to either “Use” or “Use with feeder correction”.

• It will be picked up with a nozzle that is set to “Use” for the “Available” field on the [machine] > [Specification Information] > [Pick Position Specification] screen.

• It is set to “Use” for “E: Pick Pos Correction” on the [Parts] > [Option] tab screen (that is, board data).

This screen appears when the pick-up position offset function is used. It allows to check how the pick-up

position of the object component (feeder) is corrected. If either the X or the Y correction amount exceeds

the warning zone or the error zone set up in the machine setting, the corresponding component in the

components list will change its color.

Display color

| Color of row | Status | Description |
| --- | --- | --- |
| Yellow | Warning | Exceeds warning level figure for each nozzle data set in pick-up position offset  specifications. |
| Red | Error | Exceeds error level figure for each nozzle data set in pick-up position offset  specifications. |

NOTE

Warning generated: The machine will generate an error message. The yellow or blue lamp of the signal lamp tower will flash. However, the machine can continue the operation.

Experiencing error: The machine will generate an error message when finishing producing one board and cannot continue the operation.

NOTE

The numerical values specified in the warning level and error level of the pick-up position offset specification are machine data setting items. Accessing such parameters require the administrator level of authority.

[Monitor] > [Pick Position] tab screen

Path Image  : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Operator_Manual/Displaying_Production_Monitors/Chapter_2_Basic_Operation_3_3.8_Monitor_PickPosition_tab_screen.png

• No.

Displays the parts number (that is, data number in the parts data).

• Set Number

Displays the feeder set number.

• Parts Name

Displays the component name.

• tape type

The tape type shows the type of tape when the machine processes component tapes.

• tape type

The tape type shows the type of tape when the machine processes component tapes.

It shows the method of supplying components when processing tray components

.

• X (mm), Y (mm)

Displays the amount of pick-up position offset. The figure shown is the amount of error from the

nozzle center position towards the X-direction and Y-direction.

• Pickup Rate (%)

Displays the component pick-up rate of the nozzle for which the pick-up position offset function is

on (enabled).

• Count

Displays the number of components that were picked and placed by the nozzle for which the pick-up

position offset function is on (enabled).

• [All Reset] button

This button clears and resets pick-up position offset data for all components shown on the monitor.

• [Current Reset] button

Clears and resets the pick-up position offset data for a component selected from among the

components shown on the monitor display.

3.9 “Pick Rate” Tab Screen (Pick-Up Rate Warning)

This screen appears when using the pick-up rate warning function. When clicking the tab to switch the

display, the screen allows checking for a drop in the component pick-up rate on each component or head.

The pick-up rate is reset in real-time after mounting a group of components. However, if a particular component or head is not used then its row will not appear on the display. Pick-up rates can be monitored by color during operation.

Display color

| Row color | Status | Pick-up Rate | Description |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| White | – | 100% to “Caution (yellow)”% | Pick-up rate is above “Caution (yellow)”% and below or equal to 100%. |
| Yellow | Caution | “Caution (yellow)”% to   “Warning (red)”% | Pick-up rate is above “Warning (red)”% and below or equal to “Caution  (yellow)”%. |
| Red | Warning | “Warning (red)”% to 0% | Pick-up rate is above or equal to 0% and below or equal to “Warning  (red)”%.  If the machine setting of the stop control is set to “Use”, the machine  stops while generating an alarm. The default setting is “Not Use”. |

NOTE

The values in the table above, enclosed in double quotation marks and written in percent notation, can be changed in the machine settings. You need an administrator-level authority to change them.

3.9.1 [Parts Info] Tab 

[Monitor] > [Pick Rate] tab screen

[Parts Info] tab

Path Image [Monitor] > [Pick Rate] tab screen [Parts Info] tab : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Operator_Manual/Displaying_Production_Monitors/Chapter_2_Basic_Operation_3_3.9_3.9.1_Monitor_PickRate_tab_screen.png

• No.

Displays the component number (that is, data number on the “Parts” screen).

• Table

Displays the feeder table (feeder plate location) where the component feeder is installed.

• Set No.

Displays the feeder set position at which the component feeder is installed.

• Parts name

Displays the component name.

• tape type

The “tape type” shows the type of tape when the machine processes component tapes.

It shows the method of supplying components when processing tray components.

• Pick Rate (%)

Displays the pick-up rate for each component. Rate is calculated by the following formula.

(1 - (error count / Number of components used)) x 100 = Pick-up rate

• feeder MACS

Displays the feeder MACS status.

• feeder MACS

Displays the feeder MACS status.

• Offset X(mm), Y(mm)

Displays the offset amounts of the feeder MACS.

NOTE

The feeder MACS is a function that recognizes the mark at a specific location on the feeder to perform pick-up offset correction. This function normally applies to picking up components of 1005 or smaller.

3.9.2 [Head Info] Tab

[Monitor] > [Pick Rate] tab screen

[head Info] tab

Path Image [Monitor] > [Pick Rate] tab screen [head Info] tab : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Operator_Manual/Displaying_Production_Monitors/Chapter_2_Basic_Operation_3_3.9_3.9.2_Monitor_PickRate_Head_Info_tab_screen.png

• Table

Displays the corresponding table.

• head No.

Displays the head number being used.

• nozzle Type

Displays the current nozzle type.

• head Type

Displays the method of changing the nozzle currently in use and other particulars such as automatic

nozzle change and manual nozzle change.

• Pick Rate (%)

Displays the pick-up rate for each head. Rate is calculated by the following formula.

(1 - ([error count] ÷ [Number of components used]) x 100 = Pick-up rate

• nozzle MACS

Displays the nozzle MACS status.

NOTE

The nozzle MACS is a function that detects the position of the nozzle set up on a head to perform pick-up offset correction.

Similar to the feeder MACS, this function applies to the nozzles that pick up components of 1005 or smaller.

• Center XY(mm), Offset XY(mm)

Displays the offset amounts of the nozzle MACS.

• [Current Check] button

Selecting a component (row) from among components with abnormal pick-up rates (rows shown in

“red”) and clicking this button sets “watch-and-wait” mode for that component

.

• [All Check] button

Clicking this button sets “watch-and-wait” mode for all components with abnormal pick-up rates (rows

shown in “red”).

About “Watch-and-wait” mode

The “watch-and-wait” mode is such that, if a pick-up error occurs with a component, pressing the [Current

Check] button or the [All Check] button makes the machine system memorize the pick-up rate at that point.

After that, the machine indicates by the color changes whether the pick-up rate improves or worsens.

For example, after an abnormal pick-up rate is stored in “watch-and-wait” mode, if the problem is

For example, after an abnormal pick-up rate is stored in “watch-and-wait” mode, if the problem is

eliminated and operation resumed, and the pick-up rate improves, then the color of the row(s) will change

from “pink” to “yellow” to show an improvement has been made. Conversely, if the pick-up rate becomes

even worse, then the color will change from “pink” back to “red” to show the troubleshooting was

ineffective.

The colors in the following graph show the changes in the pick-up rate, using an example when “Caution

(yellow)” is set to 99.00% and “Warning (red)” to 95.00%.

Color transitions per changes in pick-up rates

Path Image Color transitions per changes in pick-up rates : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Operator_Manual/Displaying_Production_Monitors/Chapter_2_Basic_Operation_3_3.9_3.9.2_Color_transitions_Pickrate.png

3.10 “Schedule Task” Tab Screen

When executing the schedule tasks such as the “Vacuum Check” or the “nozzle Tip Cleanliness Check”,

this screen shows the results.

The display contents are updated after each schedule task has been completed. Additionally, the error

information by head and information showing the execution results are recorded into the history.

[Monitor] > [Schedule Task] tab screen

Example: Vacuum Check

Path Image [Monitor] > [Schedule Task] tab screen Example: Vacuum Check : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Operator_Manual/Displaying_Production_Monitors/Chapter_2_Basic_Operation_3_3.10_Monitor_Schedule_Task_tab_screen.png

• Check Contents

Change the schedule task type to be displayed from the drop-down list.

Target: “Vacuum Check”, “nozzle Tip Dirt Check”, “nozzle Shaft Cleaning Blow”,

“nozzle Shape Check” and “nozzle Alignment Check”

• Schedule Task Last Date

Displays the last date and time when the schedule task was executed.

• Execution result list

Displays the last date and time when the schedule task was executed.

• Execution result list

Displays the schedule task execution result.

OK: Schedule task is completed successfully.

NG/error: Schedule task is terminated abnormally.

Blank: Schedule task is not implemented.

NOTE

If the execution result list shows tables (that is, head units) from A to D, values will be displayed only in the “A Table” columns for Single-lane type machines, and only in the “A Table” and “B Table” columns for Dual-lane or Dual-stage type machines.

NOTE

If the air-blow station is not equipped with the machine, nozzle Shaft Cleaning Blow and Buffing Check cannot be executed.

• nozzle Type

Displays the nozzle type, for which the schedule task is executed.

• Arrow buttons

Switches the display for multiple nozzle types.

• Page number display

Displays the current page number and maximum page number. This page number is not displayed when

there is only one page.

• Manual operation buttons

there is only one page.

• Manual operation buttons

Allow you to manually execute the schedule task, such as “Cleaning Blow (nozzle shaft cleaning blow)”,

“Tip Cln Check”, “Vacuum Check”, “Buffing Check”, “Shape Check”, and “Alignment Check”.

• “Table Select” drop-down list and [nozzle Stn Shutter] button

Use the “Table Select” drop-down list to select the table you want to execute the schedule task using

the manual operation buttons. You can use the [nozzle Stn Shutter] button to open or close the nozzle

station shutter of the selected table.

3.11 “Nzl Hlth Chk” Tab Screen (Nozzle Health Check)

This screen will appear only when the “nozzle health check” is set to “Use” on the [machine] button >

[machine Information] > [Installation Setting] screen.

The nozzle health check is a function that does the tasks individually performed in the previous section

“3.10 ‘Schedule Task’ Tab Screen” in a comprehensive, batch manner. The “nozzle health check” screen

shows the nozzles in bad condition.

The nozzle health check will go through a sequence in the order of 1. Vacuum Check > 2. nozzle tip

Cleanliness Check > 3. Buffing Check > 4. Shape Check > 5. Alignment Check.

If the nozzle fails any of them, the machine no longer checks that particular nozzle.

[Monitor] > [Nzl Hlth Chk] tab screen

Path Image [Monitor] > [Nzl Hlth Chk] tab screen : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Operator_Manual/Displaying_Production_Monitors/Chapter_2_Basic_Operation_3_3.11_Monitor_Nzl_Hlth_Chk_tab_screen.png

• [Health Check] button

metadata.sub_section: 3.11|“Nzl Hlth Chk” Tab Screen (Nozzle Health Check)

content:
• [Health Check] button

Pressing this button calls up the nozzle health check screen. Specify the object table (head unit) and

object ranges and press the [OK] button. The machine goes through the nozzle health check.

The object ranges are “All (all nozzles)”, “board data (nozzles set to be used in the board data)” and “NG

(nozzles once checked by the nozzle health check and calculated to be no good)”.

• Check Result Display Scope

Specifies the display range of nozzle health check results from the drop-down list.

Select “All”, “board data” or “NG” to display the corresponding results on the screen.

• Result

This shows the results of the nozzle health check.

If resulting in “NG (means no good)”, the corresponding row on the screen is displayed in red.

If even one of the check items is calculated to be no good, “NG” is displayed in the “Result” column.

• Table

Select the object table.

• head

Indicates the head number used.

• nozzle type

Indicates the type of nozzle.

metadata.sub_section: 3.11|“Nzl Hlth Chk” Tab Screen (Nozzle Health Check)

content:
• head

Indicates the head number used.

• nozzle Type

Indicates the type of nozzle.

• nozzle Stn No

Indicates the setup position of that particular nozzle on the nozzle station.

• Vacuum Check, Tip Cleanliness Check, Buffing Check, Shape Check, Alignment Check

These indicate the results of the schedule tasks individually.

• [Result Detail] button

Select a row with “Result: NG” and press the [Result Detail] button to display the details of the item

determined to be no good.

NOTE

If the “Don’t start running if nozzle Health Check NG is detected.” checkbox is marked on the “nozzle health check” screen that appears after proceeding [Setup] screen > [Software Setting] button > [Basic] tab > [Health Check] button, an error message will appear at the start of operation to prevent nozzles that are calculated “NG” from being used in production.

When this checkbox is marked, it is necessary to clean or replace the failed nozzle and perform the nozzle health check again.

“nozzle health check” setup screen

Path Image “nozzle health check” setup screen : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Operator_Manual/Displaying_Production_Monitors/Chapter_2_Basic_Operation_3_3.11_Nozzle_Health_Check_setup_screent.png

3.12 “Gap Of Pick Pos” Tab Screen (Gap of Pick-Up Position)

Displays the gap between the component center calculated by component recognition and the center of

camera field angle, for each component specified in board data, in graph form.

The re-examining of pick-up position or pick-up nozzle may be required for the component with large value

variability or biased recognition results in this graph.

[Monitor] > [Gap Of Pick Pos] tab screen

Path Image [Monitor] > [Gap Of Pick Pos] tab screen : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Operator_Manual/Displaying_Production_Monitors/Chapter_2_Basic_Operation_3_3.12_Monitor_Gap_Pick_Pos_tab_screen.png

NOTE

The displayed threshold of the gap of pick-up position amount can be set to any value by selecting “Specified” for “I: Pick Pos Check” on the [Parts] > [Option] tab screen.

When “Normal” is selected for “I: Pick Pos Check”, one-third of an opposite side of part size XY will be specified automatically as threshold of the gap of pick-up position amount.

content:
4 Preparing Component Tape

4.1 Tape Feeders

4.1.1 Setting Component Tape on Feeder

Taking up the 8 mm ZSR feeder and the 12 mm ZS feeder as examples, this section describes how to set

component tape on the feeder.

TIP

The four types of tape feeder are provided and applicable for YRM20/YRM20DL; ZSR feeder, ZS feeder, auto loading feeder, and SS feeder. Though some limitation occur when using SS feeder.

See “4.2 Handling of SS feeder” in this chapter for details.

CAUTION

Always use a tape set-up station or a power station for off-line setup to set the tape.

Do not set up component tapes onto the tape feeders on the feeder exchange carriage that has already been attached to the mounter, as the component tapes may fall into the mounter.

Step 1 Set the feeder and tape reel onto the tape set-up station.

1. Place the feeder onto the tape set-up station or power station for off-line setup.

While keeping gripping the unclamp lever of the feeder, set it to the leftmost set position (the

While keeping gripping the unclamp lever of the feeder, set it to the leftmost set position (the

point where the feeder connector is located) by sliding the feeder along the feeder guide rail of

the tape set-up station.

2. Set the tape reel for operation to the setup reel holder of the tape set-up station.

Setting feeder

Path Image Setting feeder : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Operator_Manual/Preparing_Component_Tape/Chapter_2_Basic_Operation_4_4.1_4.1.1_Setting_feeder.png

Step 2 Lift up the tape guide assembly.

1. Lay down the tape guide front lever while lifting it up.

2. Lift up the tape guide assembly.

Lifting tape guide assembly

Path Image Lifting tape guide assembly : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Operator_Manual/Preparing_Component_Tape/Chapter_2_Basic_Operation_4_4.1_4.1.1_Lifting_tape_guide_assembly.png

Step 3 Insert the component tape into the feeder.

Insert the component tape through the tape insertion slot at the rear of the feeder.

Insert the component tape through the tape insertion slot at the rear of the feeder.

Inserting component tape into feeder

Path Image Inserting component tape into feeder : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Operator_Manual/Preparing_Component_Tape/Chapter_2_Basic_Operation_4_4.1_4.1.1_Inserting_component_tape_into_feeder.png

CAUTION

Be careful not to mistake the front and back of the tape.

Step 4 Peel off the cover tape.

The tape is in two layers–one called “carrier tape” that contains the electronic components and the

other called “cover tape” that covers the components from the top. Peel of the cover tape until it

reaches to the take-up roller.

Step 5 Set the carrier tape.

Insert the carrier tape through the hole of the tape guide front lever.

Step 6 Set the cover tape.

Insert the cover tape through the notch of the tape guide assembly (or tape support plate).

At this point, make sure the cover tape is peeled off just enough to reach the take-up roller.

At this point, make sure the cover tape is peeled off just enough to reach the take-up roller.

Carrier tape and cover tape

Example: ZS feeder (12 mm)

Path Image Carrier tape and cover tape Example: ZS feeder (12 mm) : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Operator_Manual/Preparing_Component_Tape/Chapter_2_Basic_Operation_4_4.1_4.1.1_Carrier_tape_and_cover_tape_ZS_feeder.png

CAUTION

When inserting the tape through the unit, be careful not to deform the tape guide assembly with excessive force.

About tape edge delamination

12 mm, 16 mm, and 24 mm tape guides can be used without inserting the cover tape through the

notch of the tape support plate. This method is called “Edge delamination”.

In general, the Edge delamination has the advantage of reducing components waste and preventing

scratches on the component surface when the tape guide assembly is deformed or so.

However, this method may easily cause pick-up errors due to components sticking by static

However, this method may easily cause pick-up errors due to components sticking by static

electricity. Therefore, YAMAHA recommends “Delamination in advance” in which the cover tape is

inserted through the notch.

NOTE

The tape support plate of 32 mm or larger ZS feeder does not have the notch, only the Edge delamination is available.

Edge delamination

Example: ZS feeder (12 mm)

Edge delamination

Path Image Edge delamination : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Operator_Manual/Preparing_Component_Tape/Chapter_2_Basic_Operation_4_4.1_4.1.1_Edge_delamination.png

Step 7 Clamp the tape guide assembly.

While confirming that the sprocket teeth bite into the carrier tape feeding hole, push down to fix the

tape guide assembly with the tape guide front lever.

CAUTION

tape guide assembly with the tape guide front lever.

CAUTION

When clamping the tape guide assembly, the squeezing of tape guide assembly into the tape guide front lever may wear the claw of tape guide front lever. Make sure to lift up the tape guide front lever and then engage the claws of tape guide assembly and tape guide front lever to clamp the tape guide assembly.

Clamping tape guide assembly

Path Image Clamping tape guide assembly : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Operator_Manual/Preparing_Component_Tape/Chapter_2_Basic_Operation_4_4.1_4.1.1_Clamping_tape_guide_assembly.png

Step 8 Set the cover tape in the take-up roller.

Push the take-up roller lever shown in the figure to make a clearance below the take-up roller.

Insert a certain amount of the cover tape into this clearance and release the take-up roller lever to

pinch the cover tape.

Setting cover tape

pinch the cover tape.

Setting cover tape

Path Image Setting cover tape : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Operator_Manual/Preparing_Component_Tape/Chapter_2_Basic_Operation_4_4.1_4.1.1_Setting_cover_tape.png

CAUTION

Check that the cover tape, extended between the take-up roller and the tape guide assembly, is not twisted.

Step 9 Reel the cover tape to take up the slack.

Pull the cover tape lightly in the direction of the arrow and the take-up roller rotates to take up the

slack automatically.

Taking up slack of cover tape

Path Image Taking up slack of cover tape : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Operator_Manual/Preparing_Component_Tape/Chapter_2_Basic_Operation_4_4.1_4.1.1_Taking_up_cover_slack.png

CAUTION

Take up the cover tape until all slacks on the cover tape removed.

During this operation, be careful not to be winded your fingers in the roller unit while taking up the cover tape.

NOTE

The take-up roller will perform take-up motion even when the feeder is turned on.

NOTE

The take-up roller will perform take-up motion even when the feeder is turned on.

The cover tape take-up can be performed by reattaching the feeder after detaching it from the tape set-up station.

Step 10 Align the first component with the standby position.

If pressing the [FEED] button and the [BACK] button on the feeder, the tape can be transferred or

returned with the pitch setting corresponding to the feeder type.

1. Press the [FEED] button and transfer the tape temporary to locate the first component on the

pick-up position (spot: white mark or notch).

2. After pressing the component pitch and the [BACK] button once to return the component, press

the [FEED] button once and align the first component with the standby position.

Adjusting component position

Path Image Adjusting component position : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Operator_Manual/Preparing_Component_Tape/Chapter_2_Basic_Operation_4_4.1_4.1.1_Adjust_component_position.png

CAUTION

CAUTION

Make sure to align the component with the standby position by the [FEED] button. Press the [BACK] button twice or more to return the component. Then press the [FEED] button to align the component with the standby position. If aligning the standby position by the [BACK] button, the pick-up position offset of the fist component may occur.

button operations and corresponding feed pitches

| Feeder type | Setting pitch | [FEED] or [BACK] button pressed one time | [FUNC]+[FEED] or   [FUNC]+[BACK] buttons  pressed one time |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| ZS Feeder 4 mm | All pitches | 1 mm | 1 mm |
| ZS Feeder 8 mm  ZSR Feeder 8 mm | 0 | 2 mm | 1 mm |
| ZS Feeder 8 mm  ZSR Feeder 8 mm | 1 | 1 mm | 1 mm |
| ZS Feeder 8 mm  ZSR Feeder 8 mm | 2 and higher | 2 mm | 1 mm |
| ZS Feeder   12/16 mm, 24 mm, 32 mm, 44 mm, 56 mm, 72 mm,  88 mm, 104 mm | 0 | 2 mm | 2 mm |
| ZS Feeder   12/16 mm, 24 mm, 32 mm, 44 mm, 56 mm, 72 mm,  88 mm, 104 mm | 2 and higher | 2 mm | Setting pitch |

TIP

• For handling the feeder of 12 mm or wider, set the components pitch on the power station. Then, press the [FUNC] and [FEED] buttons or the [FUNC] and [BACK] buttons simultaneously. The feeder feeds the tape by the set pitch.

See Chapter 2, “5. Setting tape feed pitch” in “ZS/ZSR FEEDER User's Manual” for the setting.

• Continuous feed is possible by pressing and holding the [FEED / BACK] button.

• Continuous feed is not possible by pressing and holding the [FUNC + FEED] or [FUNC + BACK] buttons.

• See the “SS feeder User’s Manual” for setting the feed pitch of SS feeder.

Step 11 Check and adjust the tape support plate position.

If the feeder type is 12 mm or wider, you need to adjust the position of the tape support plate

according to the component shape. Loosen its two adjustment screws using a Phillips screwdriver

and adjust the position of the tape support plate between “A” and “B” in the illustration below, and

closer to “A”.

NOTE

closer to “A”.

NOTE

The cover tape is required to be adjusted when changing the tape support plate position. When the cover tape shortens, push the take-up roller lever, as the same procedure of Step 8, and pull out cover tape from take-up roller. When some slack is on cover tape, remove it.

Adjusting tape support plate position

Path Image Adjusting tape support plate position : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Operator_Manual/Preparing_Component_Tape/Chapter_2_Basic_Operation_4_4.1_4.1.1_Adjusting_tape_plate_position.png

Path Image Adjusting tape support plate position next :

Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Operator_Manual/Preparing_Component_Tape/Chapter_2_Basic_Operation_4_4.1_4.1.1_Adjusting_tape_plate_position_next.png

CAUTION

If the tape support plate is not adjusted, the components may pop out after removing the cover tape, or its pick-up position may get unstable.

Step 12 Cut the carrier tape.

Step 12 Cut the carrier tape.

Before setting the tape feeder on the machine, feed the tape out until a component is at the pick-up

position, then cut the carrier tape about 15 mm from the feeder tip.

Cutting carrier tape

Path Image Cutting carrier tape 8 mm feeder : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Operator_Manual/Preparing_Component_Tape/Chapter_2_Basic_Operation_4_4.1_4.1.1_cut_tap_8_mm.png

Path Image Cutting carrier tape 12 mm or wider feeder : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Operator_Manual/Preparing_Component_Tape/Chapter_2_Basic_Operation_4_4.1_4.1.1_cut_tap_12_mm_or_wider_feeder.png

CAUTION

If using the carrier tape without cutting the excess component, it could block the path way for discharging the tape. Cutting a hard emboss tape too short causes the carrier tape to touch at the machine slope entrance, then the feeding trouble may occur.

CAUTION

When cutting the carrier tape, do not pull the tape upwards.

CAUTION

When cutting the carrier tape, do not pull the tape upwards.

If you cut the carrier tape while pulling it upwards, the tape will have a tendency to bend, and you will not be able to insert it securely into the mounter, which may cause tape jams or malfunction.

4.1.2 Attaching Feeders onto Feeder Exchange Carriage

This section describes the procedure to set the feeder with component tape on the feeder exchange

carriage using ZSR feeder as example.

CAUTION

Always use the tape set-up station or the power station for off-line setup to set the component tapes.

Do not set component tapes onto the tape feeder on the feeder exchange carriage that has already been attached to the mounter, as the component tapes may fall into the mounter.

TIP

The four types of tape feeder are provided and applicable for YRM20/YRM20DL; ZSR feeder, ZS feeder, auto loading feeder, and SS feeder. Though some limitation occur when using SS feeder.

See “4.2 Handling of SS feeder” in this chapter for details.

Step 1 Clean the feeder plate.

Before setting the feeder on the carriage, remove dust or foreign matter from the feeder plate. Use

the feeder plate cleaning brush that comes with the machine, a vacuum cleaner (home use) or the

vacuum assembly (option) to get rid of dust or foreign matter on the feeder plate.

vacuum assembly (option) to get rid of dust or foreign matter on the feeder plate.

CAUTION

If a component or foreign matter disturbs when setting a feeder to carriage, the feeder may not sit there correctly, making it unable to pick up components in a stable manner.

Foreign object where the feeder sits in may cause electrical short circuit, possibly causing devices to be damaged.

When cleaning the feeder plate, be sure not to let foreign object contaminate the connectors.

NOTE

The air joint equipped in feeder exchange carriage can be actuated only when the carriage is attached to mounter.

Cleaning feeder plate of feeder exchange carriage

Path Image Cleaning feeder plate of feeder exchange carriage : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Operator_Manual/Preparing_Component_Tape/Chapter_2_Basic_Operation_4_4.1_4.1.2_Cleaning_feeder_plate_of_feeder_exchange_carriage.png

Step 2 Place the tape reels in the slots of the reel holder.

Step 2 Place the tape reels in the slots of the reel holder.

The storing position varies depending on the tape reel size.

A 7-inch tape reel can be stored on both upper and lower holders. Descend the reel holder to store

a 7-inch reel in the upper reel holder.

A tape reel over 7 inches are stored in the lower reel holder. Lift the upper holder as needed.

Setting tape reel in reel holder

Path Image Setting tape reel in reel holder : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Operator_Manual/Preparing_Component_Tape/Chapter_2_Basic_Operation_4_4.1_4.1.2_setting_tap_reel_in_reel_holder.png

Step 3 Set ZS feeder to carriage.

1. Grip the unclamp lever of a feeder.

2. Confirm the setting number on the carriage.

3. Place the feeder temporarily with its under rail aligned with the guide on the feeder plate side.

4. While keeping gripping the unclamp lever firmly, slide the feeder on the feeder plate to insert the

feeder to the end.

CAUTION

feeder to the end.

CAUTION

Be careful not to insert the feeder with excessive force.

Also, grip the unclamp lever firmly, or the clamp lever assembly does not open enough.

feeder exchange carriage

Setting ZS/ZSR feeder

Path Image feeder exchange carriage ZS/ZSR feeder : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Operator_Manual/Preparing_Component_Tape/Chapter_2_Basic_Operation_4_4.1_4.1.2_feeder_exchange_zs_zsr.png

Step 4 Lock the clamp lever assembly.

When releasing the unclamp lever, the clamp lever assembly will close and lock.

Confirm that the clamp lever assembly is locked firmly and the feeder does not come off.

Otherwise, the feeder may come off while mounting.

Step 5 Check the feeder set condition.

View the feeder from the side to see that “the tape guide assembly is not lifted”, “the positioning

pins at the end of the front block are inserted deep into the feeder positioning holes” and “the

pins at the end of the front block are inserted deep into the feeder positioning holes” and “the

under rail of the feeder firmly, correctly sits in the guide of feeder plate side”.

Checking feeder set condition

ZSR feeder viewed from side

Path Image Checking feeder ZSR : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Operator_Manual/Preparing_Component_Tape/Chapter_2_Basic_Operation_4_4.1_4.1.2_Check_feeder_set_condition_zsr.png

4.1.3 Attaching Feeder Exchange Carriage onto Mounter

This section describes the procedure to attach the feeder exchange carriage on the mounter.

See “4.2 Handling of SS feeder” in this chapter for procedure of attaching the feeder exchange carriage

with SS feeder to mounter.

Step 1 Clean around the clamp units of the machine.

Before attaching the carriage on the mounter, remove the dust or foreign matter around the clamp

units of the carriage at machine side. Use the feeder plate cleaning brush that comes with the

machine, a vacuum cleaner (home use) or the vacuum assembly (option) to get rid of dust or

foreign matter around the clamp units.

Cleaning clamp unit

Path Image Cleaning clamp unit : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Operator_Manual/Preparing_Component_Tape/Chapter_2_Basic_Operation_4_4.1_4.1.3_Clean_clamp_unit.png

CAUTION

CAUTION

A connector unit supplying power and air to carriage is equipped at the carriage clamp unit. Some foreign matters entering to the connector of the clamp unit might cause the short circuit to damage the equipment.

Step 2 Attach the feeder exchange carriage to the machine.

1. Move the feeder exchange carriage in front of the position to attach the carriage.

2. While holding the carriage handle, put it into the mounter straight along the carriage guide.

3. Keep fixing the carriage by holding handles while inserting the carriage to the end.

NOTE

Depending on the machine installed position, the feeder exchange carriage may move during its clamping operation due to the inclination of the floor.

Hold the handles to fix the feeder exchange carriage till the end of the carriage clamping of Steps 3 to 4.

Attaching feeder exchange carriage to machine

Attaching feeder exchange carriage to machine

Path Image Attaching feeder exchange carriage to machine : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Operator_Manual/Preparing_Component_Tape/Chapter_2_Basic_Operation_4_4.1_4.1.3_Attach_feeder.png

Step 3 Turn the clamp switch ON.

Turn the clamp switch corresponding the position where the carriage is inserted to left (ON), then

the carriage clamp unit at the mounter side moves down to clamp the carriage.

The LED indicator of the clamp switch starts blinking during clamping the carriage.

After that, the communication is checked automatically between the mounter, the carriage and the

feeders.

Carriage clamp switch

Path Image Carriage clamp switch : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Operator_Manual/Preparing_Component_Tape/Chapter_2_Basic_Operation_4_4.1_4.1.3_Carriage_clamp_switch.png

Step 4 Check the clamp switch light is on.

After the communication check between the mounter, the carriage and the feeders are completed,

After the communication check between the mounter, the carriage and the feeders are completed,

the switch indicator is changed from blinking to lighting. Let go of carriage handles.

CAUTION

While the clamp switch is blinking, do not touch the inside of machine or carriage.

The clamp unit moving down might pinch hands.

NOTE

While the safety cover or the upper cover of the mounter is open, the clamp unit doesn't move down even with turning the clamp switch.

NOTE

There is the sensor called “forward end sensor (FDR FORWARD SENSOR)” at far end of the carriage set position of the mounter. When the carriage is inserted to far end, this sensor recognizes. When this sensor doesn't recognize the carriage,the clamp units doesn't move down even with turning the clamp switch.

CAUTION

The deviation of carriage during clamping motion loads the clamp connector and the repetition of this motion may damage the clamp connector.
Make sure to keep firmly the carriage handles to attach the carriage.

4.1.4 Setting Board Data of Component Tape

After completing setting up the feeder on the machine main body, set the tape feed pitch in the board data

on the machine main body.

Step 1 Check the component tape feed pitch.

Check the component tape feed pitch prior to the operation.

Step 2 Call up the [Parts] > [Basic] tab screen.

Read out the board data. Then, open the [Parts] > [Basic] tab screen.

Step 3 Specify the “Package”.

Select the components to specify the parameters for. Then, select “tape” in the “D: Package”

drop-down list.

Setting up board data / Component tape

Step 4 Specify the “tape type”.

Select the type of component tape in the “R: tape type” drop-down list.

Setting up board data / Component tape

• By changing the “D: Package” setting, “R: tape type” setting will also be changed.

Select the feed pitch in the “F: Pitch Index” drop-down list according to the component tape to be

used.

[Parts] > [Basic] tab screen

4.1.5 Disposing of Used Cover Tape and Carrier Tape

As a daily routine, dispose of the used cover tape and carrier tape from time to time.

Disposing of used cover tape

As a result of mounting components on the production operation, the cover tape accumulates inside of

feeder. The feeder tail cover is attached with a magnet, so the accumulation of tape in the feeder

excesses its capacity, that the tail cover is pushed and opened automatically illustrated below.

Though, the periodical inspection and disposing the used cover tape before opening of tail cover is

recommended.

NOTE

As to 8 mm feeder, the tail cover opens when the accumulation reaches approximately of two 7-inch tape reels of 8 mm.

tape feeder with its tail cover automatically opened

Path Image tape feeder with its tail cover automatically opened : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Operator_Manual/Preparing_Component_Tape/Chapter_2_Basic_Operation_4_4.1_4.1.5_Tape_feeder_with_its_tail_cover_automatically_opened.png

Step 1 Check the used cover tape.

Step 2 Cut the used cover tape.

1. When the cover tape still remains, use the edge cutter installed behind the tail cover to cut off

2. Dispose the cut cover tape.

Disposing of used carrier tape

The used cut-up pieces of carrier tape are collected in the empty tape dust box as the production goes

4.1.6 Detaching Feeder Exchange Carriage

Detach the feeder exchange carriage from machine.

See “4.2 Handling of SS feeder” in this chapter for the method of detaching the carriage with SS feeder

from machine.

Step 1 Press the emergency stop button.

Step 2 Turn the clamp switch to the right (OFF).

When the clamp switch for the feeder exchange carriage to be detached is turned to the right (that

is, “OFF” position), the clamp unit on the machine side will move up. While it is moving up, the LED

indicator of the clamp switch will blink. When the feeder exchange carriage is unclamped, the

clamp switch indicator will go off.

CAUTION

While the clamp switch is blinking, do not touch the inside of machine or carriage.

The clamp unit moving down might pinch hands.

NOTE

When the emergency stop button is not pressed, the clamp unit does not move up even the clamp switch is turned OFF.

Carriage clamp switch

Carriage clamp switch

Path Image Carriage clamp switch : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Operator_Manual/Preparing_Component_Tape/Chapter_2_Basic_Operation_4_4.1_4.1.6_Carriage_clamp_switch_off.png

Step 3 Check that the clamp switch lamp is off.

Step 4 Detach the feeder exchange carriage from the machine.

Pull out straight the feeder exchange carriage by holding its handles to detach it from the machine.

Detaching feeder exchange carriage from machine

Path Image Detaching feeder exchange carriage from machine : 	Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Operator_Manual/Preparing_Component_Tape/Chapter_2_Basic_Operation_4_4.1_4.1.6_Detach_feeder_exchange_carriage_from_machine.png

4.1.7 Detaching Feeder from Feeder Exchange Carriage

Step 1 Detach feeder from the carriage.

1. Grip the unclamp lever of feeder.

2. While gripping the unclamp lever, pull the feeder straight out.

feeder exchange carriage

Step 2 Detach the reel.

Detach the set reel from the reel holder on the carriage.

4.1.8 Detaching Component Tape from Feeder

NOTE

Always use a tape set-up station (or a power station for offline setup, if equipped) to detach component tapes. Do not detach the component tapes from the feeders on the feeder exchange carriage that has already been attached to the mounter, as the component tapes may fall into the mounter.

Step 1 Set the feeder onto the tape set-up station.

1. Set the feeder onto the tape set-up station.

2. Set the tape reel into the reel holder of the tape set-up station.

NOTE

To remove a component tape from a feeder, you can also set the feeder onto any feeder set position.No connector is required.

Step 2 Dispose of the used cover tape.

Open the feeder tail cover and check if the used cover tape remains.

Dispose of the cover tape when appropriate.

TIP

See “4.1.5 Disposing of Used Cover tape and Carrier tape” in this chapter for the detailed procedure.

Step 3 Pull out the cover tape.

Press the take-up roller lever to make a clearance under the take-up roller.

Press the take-up roller lever to make a clearance under the take-up roller.

Then pull out the cover tape from the clearance.

Pulling out cover tape

Path Image Pulling out cover tape : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Operator_Manual/Preparing_Component_Tape/Chapter_2_Basic_Operation_4_4.1_4.1.8_Pull_out_cover_tape.png

Step 4 Lift the tape guide assembly.

1. While lifting up the tape guide front lever, tilt it down in the arrow direction shown in the figure

below.

2. Lift the tape guide assembly.

Step 5 Pull out carrier tape and cover tape

1. Pull out carrier tape from the tape guide front lever.

2. Pull out cover tape from the tape guide assembly.

Pullling out carrier tape and cover tape

Path Image Pullling out carrier tape and cover tape : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Operator_Manual/Preparing_Component_Tape/Chapter_2_Basic_Operation_4_4.1_4.1.8_Pull_out_carrier_tape_and_cover_tape.png

CAUTION

CAUTION

Do not pull out the cover tape forcibly. Otherwise the tape guide assembly is deformed. Pull out slowly and with care the carrier tape and cover tape. The pulling out forcibly causes the coming off the cover tape and falling off the components.

Step 6 Pull out component tape from feeder.

1. Pull out the component tape from the insertion slot at rear of feeder.

2. Rotate the tape reel to roll up the component tape.

Pulling out component tape

Path Image Pulling out component tape : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Operator_Manual/Preparing_Component_Tape/Chapter_2_Basic_Operation_4_4.1_4.1.8_Pull_out_component_tape.png

Step 7 Fix tape guide assembly.

Clamp tape guide assembly with tape guide front lever to fix it.

CAUTION

Clamp tape guide assembly with tape guide front lever to fix it.

CAUTION

When clamping the tape guide assembly, the squeezing of tape guide assembly into the tape guide front lever may wear the claw of tape guide front lever. Make sure to lift up the tape guide front lever and then engage the claws of tape guide assembly and tape guide front lever to clamp the tape guide assembly.

4.2 Handling of SS Feeder

NOTE

SS feeder is applicable with this machine.

Though it is not recommended as the following limitation occur.

The SS feeders do not support the non-stop feeder change function.

To attach the SS feeders onto the machine, you need to stop the production once and open the machine

safety cover and upper cover. To attach a feeder exchange carriage with SS feeders onto the machine,

you also need to open the machine safety cover and upper cover.

The component mounting speed of SS feeders is slower than that of ZS/ZSR feeders.

The tape feeding speed of SS feeders is relatively slower than that of ZS/ZSR feeders. Therefore, when

mounting components using SS feeders only or using them with other feeders, the machine will mount

components at a speed corresponding to the tape feeding speed of SS feeders. For this reason, the

actual mounting time will differ greatly from the mounting time calculated by the offline software (that

is, YSUP-Programming Mounter).

CAUTION

is, YSUP-Programming Mounter).

CAUTION

Attaching the feeder exchange carriage that SS feeders are set without opening machine safety cover and upper cover may damage equipment as SS feeder and upper cover interfere each other.

feeder exchange carriage

Interference between SS feeder and upper cover

Path Image Interference between SS feeder and upper cover :

Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Operator_Manual/Preparing_Component_Tape/Chapter_2_Basic_Operation_4_4.2_Interference_SSfeeder_upper_cover.png

This document describes “4.2.1 Attaching SS feeder onto feeder Exchange Carriage”, “4.2.2 Attaching

feeder Exchange Carriage with SS feeders onto Mounter”, “4.2.3 Detaching feeder exchange carriage

with SS feeders from Mounter”, and “4.2.4 Detaching SS feeder from feeder Exchange Carriage”.

4.2.1 Attaching SS Feeder onto Feeder Exchange Carriage

Step 1 Clean the feeder plate.

Remove dust or foreign matter from the feeder plate using a feeder plate cleaning brush or so,

as the same procedure of Step 1 of “4.1.2 Attaching feeders onto feeder exchange carriage” in

this chapter.

Step 2 Place a tape reel on the reel holder of the feeder exchange carriage.

Step 3 Attach the SS feeder onto the feeder exchange carriage.

1. Hold the bottom of the SS feeder and pull its handle towards you.

2. Confirm the set position number written on the feeder exchange carriage.

3. Attach the feeder temporarily with its under rail aligned with the guide on the feeder plate.

4. While pulling the handle towards you, slide the feeder on the feeder plate to surely insert it to

the end.

CAUTION

Do not apply excessive shock to the devices while attaching the feeder.

feeder exchange carriage

Attaching SS feeders on a feeder exchange carriage

The clamp lever assembly will clamp and lock when releasing the unclamp lever. Check that the

brush or so, as the same procedure of Step 1 of “4.1.3 Attaching feeder exchange carriage onto Mounter” in this chapter.

Step 2 Open the machine safety cover.

Step 3 Open the upper cover of machine.

1. Push the cover locks on both sides of upper cover and unlock the upper cover locks.

2. Open upper cover with hands.

1. Move the feeder exchange carriage in front of the position to attach the carriage.

4.2.3 Detaching Feeder Exchange Carriage with SS Feeders from Mounter

Step 1 Press the emergency stop button.

Step 2 Turn the clamp switch to the right (OFF).

When turning to right (OFF) the clamp switch corresponding to the detaching carriage, the clamp

unit of machine side will move up. The LED indicator of clamp switch blinks during moving up the

clamp unit. When the feeder is unclamped, the clamp switch indicator will go off.

CAUTION

While the clamp switch is blinking, do not touch inside of machine or carriage.

The clamp unit moving down might pinch hands.

NOTE

When the emergency stop button is not pressed, the clamp unit does not move up even the clamp switch is turned OFF.

1 Flowchart from machine Startup to End of Production

The following flowchart shows the basic procedures from starting up the machine, mounting components,

and stopping the machine after finishing up the production.

Flowchart from machine startup to end of production

content:
1.1 Pre-Operation Check

Check the following points before powering on the machine.

WARNING

BEFORE STARTING MAINTENANCE, MAKE ABSOLUTELY SURE TO POWER OFF THE machine OR THE machine IS IN THE STATE THAT THE EMERGENCY STOP BUTTON IS PRESSED.

Pre-operation checklist

metadata.chapter: 3|Flow from machine Startup to End of Production
metadata.section: 1|Flowchart from machine Startup to End of Production

content:
| Check item | Check point |
| --- | --- |
| Power supply | The specified power is connected to the power supply box located behind the front  lower right panel of the machine. |
| Supply air | The air supplied from factory with enough pressure (0.45 MPa or more) *The pressure gauge can be checked after turning on the machine. |
| Safety cover | The covers are closed. |
| Feeder | Feeders are securely attached to the feeder plate and are not tilted. No foreign objects are on the feeder and feeder plate. No used cover tape remains.  The feeder tail cover is closed. |
| Fixed feeder plate /   Feeder exchange carriage | No chips or debris are on the feeder plate.  No chips or debris are on and around the carriage clamp unit. |
| Tray Component Supply Unit (eATS30, cATS10R, sATS30R,  and sATS30NSR) | Magazine and pallet are set correctly.  No chips or debris are on the pallet.  No pallet is on the pallet stage.  Magazine door is closed.  Magazine exchange switch turns [RUN]. |
| Conveyor | No chips or debris are on the conveyor.  No obstacles such as push-up pins are under the conveyor frame. |
| Head | Each nozzle is correctly installed to the head. |
| Nozzle | The nozzle tips are not nicked, solder does not adhere to the nozzle tips, and nozzle  spring-action is smooth. |
| Empty tape dust box | No empty tape pieces are in the empty tape dust box. |

metadata.chapter: 3|Flow from machine Startup to End of Production
metadata.section: 1|Flowchart from machine Startup to End of Production

content:
1.2 Starting machine

Proceed as follows to start the machine.

WARNING

THE SIGNAL LIGHT LIGHTS UP WHEN THE machine STARTS UP THE OPERATION.

THE GREEN LAMP IS ON DURING OPERATION. THE YELLOW LAMP LIGHTS UP WHEN AN ERROR OR INTERLOCK OCCURS, AND THE RED (OR WHITE) LAMP LIGHTS UP WHEN EMERGENCY STOP IS TRIGGERED.

NEVER PLACE ANY PART OF THE BODY IN THE HEAD MOVEMENT RANGE WHILE THE GREEN LAMP IS ON.

Step 1 Turn the main switch ON.

Turn on the main switch at the front lower right of the machine, by turning it to the right.

After the system has started, the Initialization screen appears and the program necessary for

machine operation is loaded.

Main switch

Path Image Main switch : Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Operator_Manual/Flowchart_from_machine_Startup_to_End_of_Production/Chapter_3_Flow_from_machine_Startup_to_End_of_Production_1_1.2_Turn_main_switch_ON.png

Initialization screen

Initialization screen

Path Image Initialization screen Manual_image/product_manual/YRM/Operator_Manual/Flowchart_from_machine_Startup_to_End_of_Production/Chapter_3_Flow_from_machine_Startup_to_End_of_Production_1_1.2_Initialization_screen.png

Step 2 Set the carriage to the machine.

Before performing return-to-origin, set the feeder exchange carriage to the mounter, referring

“4.1.3 Attaching feeder exchange carriage onto mounter” in Chapter 2.

Step 3 Execute return-to-origin.

The “Return to origin” screen appears on the display. Press the [READY] button and then follow the

instructions on the screen to execute return-to-origin.

NOTE

If the machine is not yet ready for return-to-origin operation, the return-to-origin operation on the setup screen can be performed before going through the procedure according to “1.4 Warming Up machine” in this chapter.

content:
1.3 Selecting Operator

Assign the operator who operates the machine.

Normally, register the operator names and operation authorities (and passwords, if necessary) in advance

and select the operator from those registered.

At the time of shipping, two operators or operator groups were registered–The “Administrator” (“A group of

administrators”) who have all the complete operation authorities and the “Default operator” (“A group of

default operators”) who have a fewer operation authorities.

TIP

Active menu buttons differ depending on the operation level setup. For example, when the machine is turned on with the factory setup, the program starts up at an operation level called “Default Operator”. This “Default Operator” level is set to “Level 0” at the time of shipment to allow only basic operation items. This operation level can be changed as needed. Operators and operation items can also be added and specified by setting the password and operation level.

For more details, see “Programming Manual”.

metadata.chapter: 3|Flow from machine Startup to End of Production

Step 2 Assign the operator.

1. Pull down the GROUP NAME list on the “ID WINDOW” and select an “Administrator” or

“Operators”.

2. Select the OPERATOR NAME.

3. (If a password is set) Enter the corresponding password.

4. Press the [OK] button. The initial screen (the setup screen before selecting a board) will appear

on the display.
